revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} '''Kenneth Hopper''' (formally known as Robert D. Kenneth Hopper), a Scots engineer and now a US citizen, has made a lifelong study of different national manufacturing cultures. His studies of the origins of America's factory management culture and its influence on Japanese factory management and elsewhere after World War II have received international recognition. He is the author of numerous academic and professional articles on manufacturing and management.
==Biographical Background== He is married to Claire White Hopper, a former bank executive, and lives in [[Hackettstown, New Jersey]]. His brother, William Hopper, is an investment banker, based in London. Kenneth Hopper was born Glasgow, Scotland (May 1926).<ref>[[Will Hopper]]</ref>
Kenneth Hopper is the son of an eminent Scottish professor of chemistry who had been raised on a small farm in Northern Ireland and educated in a one-room schoolhouse through secondary school. The father's talent, however, earned him a scholarship to the Royal Academy of Science in Dublin. Professor Hopper, being Irish, was not allowed to serve in the Army during World War I, so he found employment as a graduate foreman with British Dyestuffs ( later the [[Imperial Chemical Industries]], Ltd.). The nitroglycerine section, where he worked, was known as "the land of the one-legged stools," as plant operators could not be allowed to doze off allowing a vat of new highly explosive liquid to overheat and explode. His father, in addition to his duties at the Royal Technical College, was co-author of a respected text on organic chemistry which is still being used. Professor Hopper also headed the Scottish section for the Society of Chemical Industry. Kenneth recalls many discussions about the chemical industry around the family table, particularly the issues raised about his father's opinion that the Haber labs in Germany were much superior to any British installation. This question of the superior efficacy of various nations' manufactures was thus an early perception of Kenneth Hopper's.
==Experiential Research Sources== Hopper attended "public" schools in Glasgow, graduating in 1942. During college, he worked one summer as a "production chaser" in the Cathcart Pump works and another in [[G & J Weir]]—a young man with a wheelbarrow fetching parts from remote departments, as he describes it. This also gave him the opportunity to visit many areas of the works and observe first-hand the practical problems of major manufacturers. He matriculated at [[Glasgow University]], the premiere British training ground for technology. Upon graduation in 1946, he earned First Class Honours in Mechanical Engineering, Glasgow University.
Pending graduation, he had enlisted in the British Army's [[Royal Corps of Signals|Signal Corps]] Officer Training Corps, but when he reported for duty in 1946, he was [[Demobilization of the British Armed Forces after World War II|"demobbed" along with other World War II servicemen]]. However, this brief contact with the world of radio electronics stimulated an interest in that field that flowed naturally into his later studies of the Civil Communications Section seminars. These post-war seminars were designed by the American occupation for Japanese electronics manufacturers, as there was a considerable need to keep the Japanese population informed of America's postwar reconstruction efforts there. Mr Hopper also observed that innovations such as radar, penicillin, and the jet engine came from English inventors, but each of these was turned to another nation, often America, for manufacturing. This was blatantly obvious during the war when fleets of merchant vessels had to be employed to bring parts back to Great Britain that could have been made on the island kingdom, a tragic story of submarine warfare that Hopper heard from P&G's principle fitter.{{Citation needed|date=May 2010}} Radar's refinement from a non-directional to a directional scanning device, for instance, came from the Bell Laboratories of Summit, New Jersey, USA.{{Citation needed|date=May 2010}} So, Mr. Hopper entered the manufacturing phase of his career with a keen awareness of the need for understanding how industries evolved innovative practices.
Mr. Hopper served a graduate apprenticeship at [[Metropolitan-Vickers]] from 1946 to 1948, in Manchester, England, then worked for [[Procter & Gamble]] (UK) from 1948 to 1957. There he was engineer in charge on the start-up of P&G's Manchester high pressure hydrolysis unit for making soap and on the start-up of P&G's first Standard Tower Unit for making synthetic detergents outside the US. More to the point, as a P&G engineer he was responsible for applying P&G's long-established Just-in-Time Production Control Method. In 1957, as Head of Mechanical Methods and Planning, he led the first introduction of P&G's advanced participative industrial management methods outside the US. On a 1957 visit to the US Hopper met Prof. Peter Drucker, who stimulated his interest in the work of the Civil Communications Section during the American Occupation of Japan.
Mr. Hopper expanded on those accomplishments at P&G, and from 1957 to 1962, was a consultant with Associated Industrial Consultants (AIC). He helped Irish manufacturers and the Irish Government reorganise to meet Common Market competition in the early years of the Celtic Miracle. • From 1961 to 1962 he represented the Irish Hosiery Manufacturers on the Committee on Industrial Organization (CIO) and was joint author of the CIO 1962 Report on the Irish Hosiery industry.
From 1962 to 1963, he was a member of AIC's Division of Industrial and Human Relations, working with manufacturers in the UK. Mr Hopper returned to general consulting with Belgian and French industry in 1964–65. He worked with both the funeral and wine businesses on the continent.
==Issues and Publications== A grant from the Foundation for Management Education allowed Hopper to carry out research on college graduate foremen at the Harvard Business School from 1965 to 1966, some of which was published by the [[University of Michigan]].<ref>Hopper, Kenneth, "The Growing Use of College Graduates as Foremen," Management Personnel Quarterly (6.2) Summer/Fall 1966. pp. 2–12.</ref> Entering consulting practice in the US, he provided seminars for Industrial Education International in the US, Canada and the UK and continued publishing articles on the strategy of placing college graduates in strategic manufacturing positions as foremen to get "on the ground" experience .<ref>Hopper, Kenneth,"The Nature of American Management". Moor Gate and Wall Street. Autumn number. 1966. pp. 34–51.</ref> This practice was still rare outside of American industry in the Sixties, and with the rise of a certain business school curriculum that promoted financial management over most other skills, it became rarer even in US industry in subsequent decades. His seminal article, "Can the US Stay Competitive?" raised his profile among industrialists for a time.<ref>Hopper, Kenneth, "Can the US Stay Competitive?" [[American Machinist]] (114.15), July 1970. pp. 65–70.</ref> From 1970 onwards. However, illness restricted Mr. Hopper from active consulting but allowed him to pursue research into comparative factory management from his base in New Jersey, and he developed a considerable collection of primary and secondary documents as background for a major publication. This research effort revived the interest of some academic scholars (such as Myron Tribus, emeritus Dean of the Tuck Business School at Dartmouth) in lesser known members of the US Occupation team which sparked the Japanese Miracle after World War II:
• Frank A. Polkinghorn • Charles W. Protzman • Homer M. Sarasohn • Joseph M. Juran<ref>[[Joseph M. Juran]]</ref> and, of course, • W. Edwards Deming<ref>[[W. Edwards Deming]]</ref>
In 1979, with his health much improved, Hopper took his studies to the Japanese, making a five-week tour of Japanese industry, sponsored by Mr. Bunzaemon Inoue, former chairman of the Sumitomo Group. He subsequently publishing several articles about his findings.<ref>Hopper, Kenneth,"Creating Japan's New Industrial Management: the Americans as Teachers” Human Resource Management (21.2 and 21.3) Summer/Fall 1982. pp. 13–34.</ref> He continued to publish occasionally while working with his brother, William Hopper, on a major book, ''The Puritan Gift.'' Hopper, Kenneth and William Hopper, The Puritan Gift. NY: I.B. Tauris/Macmillan, 2007. He also developed an interest in American colonial history and lectured on various subjects at Waterloo Village, a restored canal museum (now defunct) in western New Jersey. Kenneth also provided a background seminar on sailing ships for NBC news announcers, John Chancellor and David Brinkley, during the 1975 New York Bi-Centennial Tall Ships festival.
In 1994, the brothers organised and contributed to a major seminar on the work of MacArthur’s Civil Communications Section at the Japanese Embassy, London, chaired by Lord Howe, former British Foreign Secretary and attended by manufacturing, governmental and financial leaders from the European Union as well as Asian and East European nations.
Book Reviews: Among the many very positive reviews of The Puritan Gift we note that The London Financial Times called the Hoppers' book "one of the most important business books of the past decade” Stefan Stern, The Financial Times, 22 December 2009 and The Harvard Business Review reviewed it as “This astonishing book about American managerial culture … 'I’ve never read a business book that packed so much information, history, and insight into one compact volume.” Harvard Business Review, January 2010. Senior Editor, Sarah Cliffe
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== *Kenneth Hopper and William Hopper. ''The Puritan Gift.'' NY: IB Tauris/Macmillan, 2007.{{ISBN|978-1-85043-419-1}}.
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080905124248/http://deming.eng.clemson.edu/pub/den/giants_sarasohn.htm] The CCS Manual, Tokyo edition of 1949 *[http://www.puritangift.org] The Puritan Gift *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060918040620/http://deming.eng.clemson.edu/den/archive/2005.02/msg00071.html] Sensei article by Ken Hopper *[http://www.dialoguesociety.org/seminars/70-the-puritan-gift.html] Puritan Gift talk 8 March 2008 by Will Hopper
{{Authority control}}

{{pp-vandalism|small=yes}} {{Korean name|Kim}} {{Infobox person | birth_date = {{birth date|1957|6|5}} | birth_place = [[South Korea]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2011|8|27|1957|6|5}} | death_place = South Korea | other_names = Kim Tai-jong
Tong Lung (唐龍; Chinese stage name) | occupation = Actor, martial artist | years_active = 1977–1986 | module = {{Infobox Korean name|child=yes|color=transparent | hangul = 김태정 | hanja = 金泰靖 | rr = Gim Tae-jeong | mr = Kim T'aejŏng }} }} '''Kim Tai-chung''' (June 5, 1957 – August 27, 2011), also known as '''Kim Tai-jong''' or '''Tong Lung''' (唐龍; Chinese stage name), was a [[Korea]]n born [[taekwondo]] practitioner martial artist actor and businessman. Kim is perhaps best known as the ghost of [[Bruce Lee]] in 1986 film ''[[No Retreat, No Surrender]]''. ==History and early career== ===Acting=== In the 1970s, Kim made his first Hong Kong movie debut in 1977 film ''[[Snuff Bottle Connection]]'', along with [[Hwang Jang-lee|Hwang Jang Lee]] and [[Roy Horan]]. Kim played Bruce Lee’s character Billy Lo in 1978 film ''[[Game of Death#Game of Death .281978.29|Game of Death]]'', alongside [[Yuen Biao]] (who performed the acrobatics and stunts), Kim played Lee's character so well that the producers used him again a few years later. In the 1980s, Kim played Bobby Lo in 1981 film ''[[Game of Death II]]'' alongside Hwang Jang Lee, Roy Horan, To Wai-wo and Lee Hoi-san. After ''Game of Death II'', Kim returned to Korea and playing Master Bruce in 1982 film ''Jackie vs. Bruce to the Rescue'' (also known as ''Fist of Death'') along with Lee Siu-ming (A Taiwanese Stuntman and [[Jackie Chan]] look alike.), and another Korean film ''[[Miss, Please Be Patient]]'', it was released in September 1981. In June 1985, Chinese film producer [[Ng See-yuen]] was looking for an actor to play the ghost of Bruce Lee in 1986 film ''[[No Retreat, No Surrender]]'' in his American debut and final film, which marked the film debut of Belgian martial artist actor [[Jean-Claude Van Damme]] as Ivan Kraschinsky. Kim played Bruce Lee to training [[Kurt McKinney]]'s martial artist. ===Retired from acting=== After ''No Retreat, No Surrender'', Kim returned to Korea and retired from acting at the age of 29 and became a businessman. In 2008, Kim made a rare public appearance in Korea as part of a screening of ''[[Miss, Please Be Patient]]'' (아가씨 참으세요),[http://history.pifan.com/film/film_detail.asp?f_num=12&cat1=173&cat2=&uid=2413 The Puchon International Fantastic Film Festival History: Miss, Please be Patient] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721080926/http://history.pifan.com/film/film_detail.asp?f_num=12&cat1=173&cat2=&uid=2413 |date=2011-07-21 }} Retrieved on 22 July 2009. which had originally been released in 1981. Kim had played a leading role in that film. ==Death== On August 27, 2011, Kim died of stomach hemorrhage at the age of 54.{{cite web|url=http://www.hkcinemagic.com/en/people.asp?id=4168|title=Hong Kong Cinemagic - Kim Tai Jung}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cityonfire.com/kim-tai-chung-1943-2011-dead-died-death-jung/|title=R.I.P. Kim Tai Chung | work = cityonfire.com}} ==Filmography== ===Movies=== * ''[[Snuff Bottle Connection]]'' (1977) * ''[[Game of Death#Game of Death .281978.29|Game of Death]]'' (1978) * ''[[Game of Death II]]'' (1981) * ''[[Miss, Please Be Patient]]'' (1981) * ''[[Jackie and Bruce to the Rescue]]'' (1982) * ''[[No Retreat, No Surrender]]'' (1986) ===Documentary=== * ''[[Bruce Lee, the Man and the Legend]]'' (1984) ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb name|1015087|Tai Chung Kim}} {{Bruce Lee}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kim, Tai-chung}} [[Category:South Korean male film actors]] [[Category:South Korean businesspeople]] [[Category:South Korean male taekwondo practitioners]] [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:2011 deaths]] [[Category:Bruce Lee imitators]] {{SouthKorea-martialart-bio-stub}} {{Taekwondo-bio-stub}}

{{infobox Organization |name = LSE SU Alternative Investments Conference |image_border = |caption = |abbreviation = AIC |formation = 2006 |type = Student conference |purpose = Education, [[hedge fund]], [[private equity]], [[venture capital]] |headquarters = |location = London, UK |language = |leader_title = |leader_name = |main_organ = |affiliations = |num_staff = 20-30 |website = http://www.lseaic.com |image=LSE AIC logo.png |image_size=230px}}
The '''LSE SU Alternative Investments Conference''' (also known as the '''LSE AIC''') is an international conference on [[hedge fund]]s, [[private equity]] and [[venture capital]] held annually in London, United Kingdom by the Alternative Investments Society (AIS), a Student’s Union society at the [[London School of Economics and Political Science]] (LSE).<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://lseaic.com/|title=Home - LSE AIC|website=LSE AIC|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-02}}</ref>
==History== The Alternative Investments Society was founded in 2006 by a group of undergraduate students at the LSE, and continues to be run by students from the university.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.lseaic.com/about/|title=About - LSE AIC|work=LSE AIC|access-date=2017-08-02|language=en-US}}</ref> The first Alternative Investments Conference was a one-day event hosted on the LSE campus in 2007, and was attended by 200 students who heard from several notable investors. The AIC has evolved considerably over its twelve-year history, having changed venues and ultimately becoming the world’s largest student conference on hedge funds, private equity and venture capital.
==Overview==
=== Format === The Conference takes place over two days at the five-star London Marriott Hotel Grosvenor Square, bringing together over 40 senior level industry leaders (see [[LSE Alternative Investment Conference#Notable past speakers|notable past speakers]]) and 320 student delegates from many of the world’s leading educational institutions. Delegates come from a range of backgrounds, including both undergraduates and postgraduates studying finance, law, engineering, history as well as many other disciplines.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.lseaic.com/about/demographics/|title=Demographics - LSE AIC|work=LSE AIC|access-date=2017-08-02|language=en-US}}</ref> Admission to the Conference is competitive, with only 4.3% of applicants to AIC 2017 being selected to attend.<ref name=":0" /> The Conference is international in character, with applicants coming from over 200 universities located across more than 120 countries world wide.
The format of the Conference sees delegates attend keynote speeches, panel discussions and workshop sessions designed to allow for them to learn from and interact with experienced professionals from within the investment community. Networking events are also held during the Conference by the AIC’s partner firms, as well as a dinner for all attending delegates hosted during the evening of the first day of the event. Sponsor firms of the AIC include [[Point72 Asset Management]], [http://www.dartmouthpartners.com Dartmouth Partners], [[Canada Pension Plan Investment Board]], [[Terra Firma Capital Partners]], [[GAM (company)|GAM,]] [https://amicusplc.co.uk Amicus], [[Bain & Company]], [[Bain Capital]], [[3i]], [[Patron Capital]], [[Lansdowne Partners]], [http://www.stableam.com/disclaimer.asp Stable Asset Management], and [[Dechert]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.lseaic.com/sponsors/|title=Sponsors - LSE AIC|work=LSE AIC|access-date=2017-08-02|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== In the media === The Conference is well regarded on campus, as well as outside of the LSE, having been cited in the media a number of times<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/student/career-planning/getting-job/its-not-easy-to-become-a-hedge-fund-manager-you-need-passion-and-instinct-775907.html|title=It's not easy to become a hedge fund manager - you need passion and|date=2008-01-31|work=The Independent|access-date=2017-08-02|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/fb5b4b3a-0ae2-11df-8a26-00144feabdc0.html?ft_site=falcon&desktop=true#axzz15mV5hIff|title=Hedgie lessons|last=Mychasuk|first=Emiliya|date=2010-01-27|work=Financial Times|access-date=2017-08-02|last2=Terazono|first2=Emiko|issn=0307-1766}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/guy-hands-terra-firma-junior-staff-houses-bonuses-2017-1?r=US&IR=T|title=One of the UK's biggest private equity companies has stopped giving juniors bonuses — but is buying them houses in London instead|work=Business Insider|access-date=2017-08-02|language=en}}</ref> and described by the Financial Times as 'a chance for the best brains in asset management to meet'.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/03345f02-1288-11df-a611-00144feab49a|title=Subscribe to read|website=Financial Times|access-date=2017-08-02}}</ref>
Several keynote sessions from past conferences are also available to watch online.<ref>{{Citation|last=LSE SU AIC|title=LSE SU Alternative Investments Conference 2015 {{!}} Guy Hands|date=2015-12-01|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0xyoD7TaFPs&t=29s|accessdate=2017-08-02}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=GAM|title=LSE Alternative Investment Conference 2016 - Alexander Friedman, GAM|date=2016-03-09|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZgDxCouvSgA|accessdate=2017-08-02}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=Oaktree Capital|title=Jay Wintrob: LSE Alternative Investments Conference|date=2017-02-17|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YTvPiXqny2o|accessdate=2017-08-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://vimeo.com/29879763|title=AIC 2011 Hugh Hendry, Eclectica Asset Management and Steven Drobny, Drobny Global Advisors|website=Vimeo|access-date=2017-08-02}}</ref>
===Notable past speakers=== Several notable past speakers at the AIC include: *[[David Rubenstein]] (Co-Founder & Co-CEO, [[The Carlyle Group]]) *[[Daniel A. D'Aniello]] (Co-Founder & Chairman, [[The Carlyle Group]]) *[[David Bonderman]] (Co-Founder, [[TPG Capital]]) *[[Guy Hands]] (Founder & Chairman, [[Terra Firma Capital Partners]]) *[[Luke Ellis]] (CEO, [[Man Group]]) *[[Marc Rowan]], (Co-Founder, [[Apollo Global Management]]) *[[Glenn Hutchins]] (Co-Founder, [[Silver Lake Partners]]) *[[Jim Breyer]] (Founder & CEO, [[Breyer Capital]]) *[[Arif Naqvi]] (Founder & CEO, [[The Abraaj Group]]) *[[Paul Singer (businessman)|Paul Singer]] (Founder & CEO, [[Elliott Management Corporation]]) *[[Marc Lasry]] (Co-Founder & CEO, [[Avenue Capital Group]]) *[[Michael Hintze|Sir Michael Hintze]] (Founder & CEO, [[CQS (Hedge Fund)|CQS]]) *[[Emmanuel Roman]] (CEO, [[PIMCO]]) *[[James Chanos]] (Founder & President, [https://www.kynikos.com/kynikos/web/me.get?web.home Kynikos Associates]) *[[Josef Ackermann|Dr Josef Ackermann]] (Former CEO, [[Deutsche Bank]]) *[[Howard Davies (economist)|Sir Howard Davies]] (Former Director of the LSE & former Chairman of the [[Financial Services Authority]]) *[[Michelle Scrimgeour]] (EMEA CEO, [[Columbia Threadneedle]]) *[[Andrew Large|Sir Andrew Large]] (Former Deputy Governor, [[Bank of England]]) *[[Gillian Tett]] (U.S. Managing Editor, [[Financial Times]]) *[[Anthony Scaramucci]] (Founder, [[SkyBridge Capital]])
==The 2019 Conference== The Alternative Investments Conference 2019 will be held at the London Marriott Hotel Grosvenor Square, on January 21 & 22 2019. This will be the thirteenth annual edition of the Conference, and will mark over 3,300 students having attended the AIC since its inception.

{{Other people|Lawrence Washington|Lawrence Washington (disambiguation){{!}}Lawrence Washington}} {{Good Article}} {{Infobox military person |name = Lawrence Berry Washington |birth_name = Lawrence Berry Washington |birth_date = {{Birth date|1811|11|26}} |birth_place = "[[Cedar Lawn]]" near [[Charles Town, West Virginia|Charles Town]], [[Virginia]] (now [[West Virginia]]), [[United States]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|1856|09|21|1811|11|26}} |death_place = [[Missouri River]] near [[Rocheport, Missouri|Rocheport]], [[Missouri]], United States |residence = |nationality = American |ethnicity = [[European American]] |citizenship = United States of America |laterwork = lawyer, military officer, author, [[California Gold Rush#Forty-niners|Forty-niner]], [[Border Ruffian]] |religion = [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopalian]] |relations = [[John Thornton Augustine Washington]] (father)
Elizabeth Conrad Bedinger (mother)
[[Benjamin Franklin Washington]] (brother)
[[Robert Rutherford (congressman)|Robert Rutherford]] (great-grandfather)
[[Samuel Washington]] (great-grandfather)
[[George Washington]] (great-granduncle) |battles = [[Mexican–American War]] |allegiance = {{flagicon|United States}} United States of America |serviceyears = 1846–48 (USA) |rank= [[Second lieutenant]] |branch = [[United States Army]] }} '''Lawrence Berry Washington''' (November 26, 1811 – September 21, 1856) was an American lawyer, military officer, author, [[California Gold Rush#Forty-niners|Forty-niner]], [[Border Ruffian]], and a member of the Washington family. Washington was born on his family's [[Cedar Lawn]] plantation near [[Charles Town, West Virginia|Charles Town]], [[Virginia]] (present-day [[West Virginia]]) and was the eldest of 13 children. He practiced law, then served as a [[second lieutenant]] in the [[Virginia militia|Virginia Volunteers]] during the [[Mexican–American War]]. During his service in the war, Washington reportedly wore the sword of his great-granduncle George Washington. Following the Mexican–American War, Washington traveled to California in 1849 as a [[California Gold Rush#Forty-niners|Forty-niner]] in the [[California Gold Rush]] and authored the novel, ''A Tale to be Told Some Fifty Years Hence''. Washington then relocated east to Missouri in the 1850s, where he remained for a few years and fought as a [[Border Ruffian]] during the [[Bleeding Kansas]] confrontations over [[Slavery in the United States|slavery]] along the border between [[Kansas Territory]] and Missouri. While under the command of Captain [[Henry Clay Pate]], Washington was present at the June 1856 [[Free-Stater (Kansas)|Free-Stater]] attack known as [[Battle of Black Jack]], where he sustained minor injuries. Washington died by drowning after falling overboard from a [[steamboat]] on the [[Missouri River]] in September 1856. His family's descendants claim Washington was murdered by [[Jayhawker]]s. Washington was a great-grandson of [[Samuel Washington]], a great-grandnephew of first [[President of the United States]] [[George Washington]], a great-grandson of [[Robert Rutherford (congressman)|Robert Rutherford]], a [[United States House of Representatives|United States House Representative]] from Virginia, and a nephew of [[Henry Bedinger|Henry Bedinger III]], also a member of the U.S. House of Representatives. == Early life and family == [[File:Cedar Lawn, West Virginia.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Washington's [[birthplace]], "[[Cedar Lawn]]" near [[Charles Town, West Virginia|Charles Town]] in [[Jefferson County, West Virginia]]. "[[Cedar Lawn]]" was built by Washington's father, [[John Thornton Augustine Washington]], in 1825.]] Lawrence Berry Washington was born on November 26, 1811, at "[[Cedar Lawn]]" plantation near [[Charles Town, West Virginia|Charles Town]] in [[Jefferson County, West Virginia|Jefferson County]], [[Virginia]] (present-day [[West Virginia]]) and was the eldest son of [[John Thornton Augustine Washington]] and his wife Elizabeth Conrad Bedinger Washington.{{Harvnb|Welles|1879|pp=208–209.}}{{Harvnb|Kunitz|Haycraft|Hadden|1933|p=51.}}{{Harvnb|Bacon|1908|p=755.}} Through his father, Washington was a grandson of Thornton Augustine Washington, a great-grandson of [[Samuel Washington]], and a great-grandnephew of first [[President of the United States]] [[George Washington]]. Through his mother, he was a great-grandson of [[Robert Rutherford (congressman)|Robert Rutherford]], a [[United States House of Representatives|United States House Representative]] from Virginia, and a nephew of [[Henry Bedinger|Henry Bedinger III]], also a member of the U.S. House of Representatives who later served as [[United States Ambassador to Denmark|Chargé d'Affaires]] and [[United States Ambassador to Denmark|Minister to Denmark]] for President [[Franklin Pierce]].{{Harvnb|McGee|1973|p=3.}} Washington was raised in a large family at Cedar Lawn, where he had four brothers and eight sisters:{{Harvnb|Cooper County, Missouri Genealogical Web (GenWeb) Project|2012|p=1.}}{{Harvnb|Harrison|2005|pp=1943–1945.}} {{clear}} {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * Daniel Bedinger Washington (born 1814) * Virginia Thornton Washington (1816–1838) * Sally Eleanor Washington (1818–1858) * [[Benjamin Franklin Washington]] (1820–1872) * Georgiana Augusta Washington Smith (born 1822) * Mary Elizabeth Washington Asbury (born 1824) * John Thornton Augustine Washington (1826–1894) * Mildred Berry Washington (September 3–12, 1827) * Mildred Berry Washington Bedinger (1829–1871) * George Washington (born 1830) * Susan Ellsworth Washington Bedinger (born 1833) * Henrietta Gray Washington (1835–1838) }} Because of his large number of siblings, Washington's inheritance from his father in 1841 was not sizable, and he and his brothers pursued a number of business opportunities to build their personal wealth.{{Harvnb|Wallace|1951|p=110.}} Washington studied jurisprudence, and was operating a law practice in Charles Town by November 1844.{{cite news| title =Lawrence B. Washington, Attorney and Counsellor at Law| newspaper =Spirit of Jefferson| publication-place =[[Charles Town, West Virginia]]| date =November 8, 1844| page =4| url =http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026788/1844-11-08/ed-1/seq-4/| accessdate =April 21, 2015| deadurl =no| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20160309115115/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026788/1844-11-08/ed-1/seq-4/| archivedate =March 9, 2016| df =}}{{cite news| title =If Washington Had Become Our King| newspaper =The Oregon Daily Journal| publication-place =[[Portland, Oregon]]| date =February 21, 1909| page =30| url =https://www.newspapers.com/image/78337956/| accessdate =April 21, 2015| deadurl =no| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20160303232934/http://www.newspapers.com/image/78337956/| archivedate =March 3, 2016| df =}} He advertised himself in the ''Spirit of Jefferson'' newspaper as an agent for landowners in the [[Virginia Military District]] in Ohio and offered his services for the legal defense and tax payments for those lands. By August 1845, he and his brother Benjamin Franklin Washington were engaged in a real estate venture, selling lots of {{convert|640|acres|km2}} along the [[Kanawha River]] in [[Mason County, West Virginia|Mason County]].{{cite news| title =For Sale In Mason County, Virginia| newspaper =Spirit of Jefferson| publication-place =[[Charles Town, West Virginia]]| date =August 29, 1845| page =3| url =http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026788/1845-08-29/ed-1/seq-3/| accessdate =April 21, 2015| deadurl =no| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20160306214716/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026788/1845-08-29/ed-1/seq-3/| archivedate =March 6, 2016| df =}} == Military career == Washington subsequently served as a [[second lieutenant]] in the [[Virginia militia|Virginia Volunteers]] during the [[Mexican–American War]].{{Harvnb|Gardner|1853|p=190.}} At the onset of the war, Washington enrolled in the Jefferson County company (Company K), Second Battalion, of the Virginia Regiment in the [[United States Army]] on December 6, 1846. Two and a half weeks later he was selected by a committee of prominent citizens in Charles Town on December 24, 1846, to serve in the company as a second lieutenant.{{Harvnb|West Virginia Department of Archives and History|1911|p=190.}}{{Harvnb|Bushong|1972|p=133.}}{{Harvnb|Bushong|1972|p=508.}} Washington and his company departed Charles Town on January 4, 1847, and they reached the [[Brazos River]] in Texas by March 12.{{Harvnb|Bushong|1972|p=134.}} According to the ''Richmond Enquirer'', Washington wore the sword of his great-granduncle George Washington while serving in Mexico.{{cite news| title =The Sword of Washington in Mexico| newspaper =[[The Baltimore Sun|The Sun]]| publication-place =[[Baltimore, Maryland]]| date =January 20, 1847| page =1| url =https://www.newspapers.com/image/34977005/| accessdate =April 21, 2015| deadurl =no| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20160304031548/http://www.newspapers.com/image/34977005/| archivedate =March 4, 2016| df =}}{{cite news| title =The Sword of Washington in Mexico| newspaper =The Evening Post| publication-place =[[New York City]]| date =January 16, 1847| page =2| url =https://www.newspapers.com/image/33777719/| accessdate =April 21, 2015| deadurl =no| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20160304060813/http://www.newspapers.com/image/33777719/| archivedate =March 4, 2016| df =}}{{cite news| title =Washington's Sword| newspaper =[[The Times-Picayune]]| publication-place =[[New Orleans, Louisiana]]| date =January 20, 1847| page =2| url =https://www.newspapers.com/image/25546799/| accessdate =April 21, 2015| deadurl =no| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20160303222806/http://www.newspapers.com/image/25546799/| archivedate =March 3, 2016| df =}} Of the sword carried by Washington, the ''Richmond Enquirer'' stated, "this precious relic will in itself be potent enough to rally every member of the Virginia regiment to the noblest and most generous deeds." In July 1847, the ''Charlestown Free Press'' in Charles Town published a letter from Washington in which he praised then General [[Zachary Taylor]] as a potential [[Whig Party (United States)|Whig]] candidate for President.{{cite news| title =Gen. Taylor: We Recommend the Following from the ''Richmond Whig''| newspaper =Boon's Lick Times| publication-place =[[Fayette, Missouri]]| date =July 31, 1847| page =2| url =https://www.newspapers.com/image/49693806/| accessdate =April 21, 2015| deadurl =no| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20160304054913/http://www.newspapers.com/image/49693806/| archivedate =March 4, 2016| df =}} Washington remarked that Taylor was "a firm and true Whig" and that when he looked at Taylor, he remarked to himself "there is the President of the United States that is to be." While at [[Fort Monroe]] in [[Hampton, Virginia|Hampton]], Virginia, after the company's return east, Washington drafted a letter dated May 7, 1848, to [[United States Secretary of War]] [[William L. Marcy]] offering to raise a company of troops to fight Mexican armed forces in Oregon or elsewhere on the condition that he be granted a [[Captain (United States)|captaincy]].{{Cite web | last = Washington | first = Lawrence Berry | title = Letter from Lawrence Berry Washington, Fortress Monroe, Va. to William L. Marcy, ALS, May 7, 1848 | publisher = [[WorldCat]] | year = 1848 |oclc=122466373 }} == Later careers and pursuits == Following his service in the Mexican–American War, Washington joined the Charles Town Mining Company and traveled to California in 1849 as a [[California Gold Rush#Forty-niners|Forty-niner]] in the [[California Gold Rush]] with his brother Benjamin Franklin Washington; however, there are no existing records of Washington finding gold during his pursuit.{{Harvnb|Wayland|1998|p=241.}} While in California, Washington authored the novel, ''A Tale to be Told Some Fifty Years Hence'', which was published in 1853.{{Harvnb|Washington|1853|p=}} Washington then relocated east to Missouri in the 1850s, where he remained for a few years and fought as a [[Border Ruffian]] during the [[Bleeding Kansas]] confrontations over [[Slavery in the United States|slavery]] along the border between [[Kansas Territory]] and Missouri. While in Missouri, Washington wrote poetry and contributed to local newspapers. He returned to Virginia later in the 1850s. While in Virginia, Washington again applied for a military office in March 1855 under an expansion in the [[Regular Army (United States)|Regular Army]] after Congress added two new regiments to protect the large additional territory obtained from Mexico.{{Harvnb|Mahon|Danysh|1972|p=18.}}{{cite news| title =Appointments in the New Regiments| newspaper =Richmond Dispatch| publication-place =[[Richmond, Virginia]]| date =March 12, 1855| page =1| url =https://www.newspapers.com/image/79770740/| accessdate =April 21, 2015| deadurl =no| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20160304061012/http://www.newspapers.com/image/79770740/| archivedate =March 4, 2016| df =}}{{cite news| title =News from all Quarters.| newspaper =Squatter Sovereign| publication-place =[[Atchison, Kansas]]| date =April 10, 1855| page =3| url =https://www.newspapers.com/image/49604697/| accessdate =April 21, 2015| deadurl =no| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20160304060721/http://www.newspapers.com/image/49604697/| archivedate =March 4, 2016| df =}} By December 1855, Washington was in [[Kanawha County, West Virginia|Kanawha County]] where he established a joint stock company to promote emigration to Kansas.{{cite news| title =Major L. B. Washington is forming a joint stock company in Kanawha county, Va., for emigration to Kansas.| newspaper =Richmond Dispatch| publication-place =[[Richmond, Virginia]]| date =December 7, 1855| page =1| url =https://www.newspapers.com/image/79789326/| accessdate =April 21, 2015| deadurl =no| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20160304001952/http://www.newspapers.com/image/79789326/| archivedate =March 4, 2016| df =}}{{cite news| title =Major L. B. Washington is forming a joint stock company in Kanawha county, Va., for emigration to Kansas.| newspaper =[[The Baltimore Sun|The Sun]]| publication-place =[[Baltimore, Maryland]]| date =December 10, 1855| page =4| url =https://www.newspapers.com/image/33761681/| accessdate =April 21, 2015| deadurl =no| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20160303220443/http://www.newspapers.com/image/33761681/| archivedate =March 3, 2016| df =}} He returned to Missouri in 1856, where he continued to serve as a Border Ruffian.{{cite news| title =Major L. B. Washington, of Jefferson county, Va., was among the wounded in Capt. Pate's company in Kansas a few days since.| newspaper =Richmond Dispatch| publication-place =[[Richmond, Virginia]]| date =June 25, 1856| page =2| url =https://www.newspapers.com/image/79765777/| accessdate =April 21, 2015| deadurl =no| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20160303232110/http://www.newspapers.com/image/79765777/| archivedate =March 3, 2016| df =}} Washington served as a Border Ruffian in a company under the command of Captain [[Henry Clay Pate]].{{cite news| title =The Black Jack Point Affray.| newspaper =Richmond Dispatch| publication-place =[[Richmond, Virginia]]| date =June 21, 1856| page =4| url =https://www.newspapers.com/image/79765496/| accessdate =April 21, 2015| deadurl =no| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20160304025826/http://www.newspapers.com/image/79765496/| archivedate =March 4, 2016| df =}}{{cite news| title =The Latest "Battle" in Kansas.| newspaper =[[The Baltimore Sun|The Sun]]| publication-place =[[Baltimore, Maryland]]| date =June 20, 1856| page =1| url =https://www.newspapers.com/image/34630647/| accessdate =April 21, 2015| deadurl =no| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20160303222940/http://www.newspapers.com/image/34630647/| archivedate =March 3, 2016| df =}} On June 2, 1856, Washington and his company were attacked at their encampment near [[Baldwin City, Kansas]] by anti-slavery [[Free-Stater (Kansas)|Free-Stater]] forces under the leadership of abolitionist [[John Brown (abolitionist)|John Brown]].{{Harvnb|Oates|1984|p=154.}} Upon seeing that the Free-Staters' reinforcements were nearby, Captain Pate instructed Washington to send for reinforcements of their own. Washington departed during the early stages of the engagement to send for reinforcements, and sustained slight wounds. Pate surrendered to Brown and his men, and Brown took 25 of the Border Ruffians as prisoners. The attack came to be known as the [[Battle of Black Jack]] or the Black Jack Point Affray. == Death and legacy == Washington died by drowning after falling overboard from a [[steamboat]] on the [[Missouri River]] near [[Rocheport, Missouri|Rocheport]] in [[Boone County, Missouri|Boone County]], Missouri, on the night of September 21, 1856.{{cite news| title =Drowned.| newspaper =Richmond Dispatch| publication-place =[[Richmond, Virginia]]| date =November 10, 1856| page =2| url =https://www.newspapers.com/image/79780478/| accessdate =April 21, 2015| deadurl =no| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20160304043953/http://www.newspapers.com/image/79780478/| archivedate =March 4, 2016| df =}}{{cite news| title =Drowned.| newspaper =[[The Baltimore Sun|The Sun]]| publication-place =[[Baltimore, Maryland]]| date =November 11, 1856| page =4| url =https://www.newspapers.com/image/34631138/| accessdate =April 21, 2015| deadurl =no| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20160304062014/http://www.newspapers.com/image/34631138/| archivedate =March 4, 2016| df =}} Washington family descendants claim that Washington was murdered by Kansas [[Jayhawker]]s because of his pro-slavery [[Southern United States|Southern]] sympathies and possibly in retaliation for his participation in the Bleeding Kansas conflicts as a Border Ruffian. In remarking of Washington's death, the ''[[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]]'' stated that the incident "gave Kansas the name of 'Bloody'".{{cite news| title =If Washington Had Been King: Sturdy Missouri Countryman Would Now Be on the Throne at National Capitol| newspaper =[[The Washington Post]]| publication-place =[[Washington, D.C.]]| date =September 6, 1908| page =1| url =https://www.newspapers.com/image/28869081/| accessdate =April 21, 2015| deadurl =no| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20160303214244/http://www.newspapers.com/image/28869081/| archivedate =March 3, 2016| df =}}{{cite news| title =If Washington Had Been King: Sturdy Missouri Countryman Would Now Be on the Throne at National Capitol| newspaper =[[The Cincinnati Enquirer]]| publication-place =[[Cincinnati, Ohio]]| date =September 5, 1908| page =14| url =https://www.newspapers.com/image/33446207/| accessdate =April 21, 2015| deadurl =no| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20160303225950/http://www.newspapers.com/image/33446207/| archivedate =March 3, 2016| df =}} Washington was a lifelong [[bachelor]], and he died without issue. His younger brother, John Thornton Augustine Washington, memorialized Washington by naming his fifth child Lawrence Berry Washington; he was born in [[San Antonio, Texas|San Antonio]], Texas, on July 12, 1869.{{Harvnb|Welles|1879|p=242.}} ==Theoretical American royal succession== According to a May 1908 article in ''The Scrap Book'' entitled "If Washington Had Been Crowned" and later in a February 1951 article in ''[[Life (magazine)|Life]]'' entitled "If Washington Had Become King: A Carpenter or an Engineer Might Now Rule the U.S.," Lawrence Berry Washington would have succeeded his father, John Thornton Augustine Washington, as "king" of the United States had his great-granduncle, George Washington, accepted the position of monarch rather than that of president.{{Harvnb|Wallace|1951|p=108.}}{{Harvnb|Smolenyak|2008|p=27.}} Throughout the course of 1908 and 1909, the theoretical Washington family royal succession was further publicized in the ''St. Louis Post-Dispatch'', ''The Washington Post'', ''[[The Cincinnati Enquirer]]'', ''Pittsburgh Daily Post'', ''The Oregon Daily Journal'', and ''The Wichita Daily Eagle''.{{cite news| title =The Man Who Would Now Be King of the United States| newspaper =Pittsburgh Daily Post| publication-place =[[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]]| date =August 16, 1908| page =21| url =https://www.newspapers.com/image/86589411/| accessdate =April 21, 2015| deadurl =no| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20160303231406/http://www.newspapers.com/image/86589411/| archivedate =March 3, 2016| df =}}{{cite news| title =Washington's Nearest Heirs: One of Them is a Druggist at Index, Missouri.| newspaper =The Wichita Daily Eagle| publication-place =[[Wichita, Kansas]]| date =August 12, 1908| page =4| url =https://www.newspapers.com/image/63219130/| accessdate =April 21, 2015| deadurl =no| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20160304023825/http://www.newspapers.com/image/63219130/| archivedate =March 4, 2016| df =}} Following the laws of male preference [[primogeniture]] [[Succession to the British throne|succession]] recognized by the [[Kingdom of Great Britain]] at the time of [[American Revolution|American independence]], Lawrence Berry Washington would have been the lawful [[heir apparent]] to his father, who was the eldest son of Thornton Augustine Washington, who in turn was the eldest son of Samuel Washington, George Washington's eldest full brother. A theoretical "King Lawrence I of the United States" would have had a reign spanning from his father's death in 1841 until his own death in 1856. Following his death, the American crown would have passed to his next eldest brother, Daniel Bedinger Washington. ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==Bibliography== * {{Cite journal| last=Bacon| first=E. {{no footnotes|date=April 2013}}
[[File:Liquidnitrogen.jpg|thumb|Liquid nitrogen]] '''Liquefaction of gases''' is physical conversion of a [[gas]] into a [[liquid]] state ([[condensation]]).
==Details== The processes are used for scientific, industrial and commercial purposes. Many gases can be put into a liquid state at normal [[atmospheric pressure]] by simple cooling; a few, such as [[carbon dioxide]], require pressurization as well. [[Liquefaction]] is used for analyzing the fundamental properties of gas molecules (intermolecular forces), for storage of gases, for example: [[liquefied petroleum gas|LPG]], and in [[refrigeration]] and [[air conditioning]]. There the gas is liquefied in the ''[[condenser (laboratory)|condenser]]'', where the [[heat of vaporization]] is released, and evaporated in the ''[[evaporator]],'' where the heat of vaporization is absorbed. [[Ammonia]] was the first such [[refrigerant]], and is still in widespread use in industrial refrigeration, but it has largely been replaced by compounds derived from [[petroleum]] and [[halogen]]s in residential and commercial applications.
[[Liquid oxygen]] is provided to hospitals for conversion to gas for patients with breathing problems, and [[liquid nitrogen]] is used in the medical field for [[cryosurgery]], and by inseminators to freeze [[semen]]. Liquefied [[chlorine]] is transported for eventual solution in water, after which it is used for water purification, sanitation of [[industrial waste]], sewage and swimming pools, bleaching of pulp and textiles and manufacture of [[carbon tetrachloride]], [[glycol]] and numerous other organic compounds as well as [[phosgene]] gas.
Liquefaction of [[helium]] ([[Liquid helium|<sup>4</sup>He]]) with the precooled [[Hampson–Linde cycle]] led to a [[Nobel Prize]] for [[Heike Kamerlingh Onnes]] in 1913. At ambient pressure the boiling point of [[liquid helium|liquefied helium]] is {{convert|4.22|K|°C|abbr=on}}. Below 2.17 K liquid <sup>4</sup>He becomes a [[superfluid]] ([[Nobel Prize]] 1978, [[Pyotr Kapitsa]]) and shows characteristic properties such as heat conduction through [[second sound]], zero [[viscosity]] and the [[Superfluid helium-4|fountain effect]] among others.
The liquefaction of gases is a complicated process that uses various compressions and expansions to achieve high pressures and very low temperatures, using, for example, [[turboexpander]]s.
The liquefaction of air is used to obtain [[nitrogen]], [[oxygen]], and [[argon]] and other atmospheric [[noble gas]]es by separating the air components by [[fractional distillation]] in a [[Air separation|cryogenic air separation unit]].
==History==
{{see|Timeline of low-temperature technology}}
==Liquid air==
{{main|Liquid air}}
===Linde's process===
Air is liquefied by the [[Linde process]], in which air is alternately compressed, cooled, and expanded, each expansion results in a considerable reduction in temperature. With the lower temperature the molecules move more slowly and occupy less space, so the air changes phase to become liquid.
===Claude's process=== Air can also be liquefied by [[Georges Claude|Claude]]'s process in which the gas is allowed to expand [[isentropic process|isentropically]] twice in two chambers. While expanding, the gas has to do work as it is led through an [[expansion turbine]]. The gas is not yet liquid, since that would destroy the turbine. Commercial air liquefication plants bypass this problem by expanding the air at [[supercritical fluid|supercritical]] pressures.<ref>{{cite book |title=Industrial Gases |last=Greenwood |first=Harold Cecil |year=1919 |publisher=D. Van Nostrand |page=87 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Qz9DAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA87}}</ref> Final liquefaction takes place by [[isenthalpic process|isenthalpic]] expansion in a [[thermal expansion valve]].

{{more footnotes|date=October 2010}} {{Infobox person | name =Meyer Guggenheim | image =Meyer Guggenheim.jpg | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1828|2|1}} | birth_place =[[Lengnau, Aargau|Lengnau]], [[Aargau]], Switzerland | death_date = {{Death date and age|1905|3|15|1828|2|1}} | death_place = [[Palm Beach, Florida]], United States | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = | nationality = | other_names = | known_for =[[Guggenheim family]] | education = | employer = | occupation = | title = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | religion = | spouse = | partner = | children =[[Isaac Guggenheim]]

[[Cora Guggenheim]] | parents = | relatives = | signature = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Meyer Guggenheim''' (February 1, 1828 – March 15, 1905) was the [[patriarch]] of what became known as the [[Guggenheim family]]. ==Biography== He was born in [[Lengnau, Aargau|Lengnau]], [[Aargau]], Switzerland on February 1, 1828. He was of [[Ashkenazi Jew]]ish ancestry and emigrated to the United States in 1847. He started out in the importing business, but made his and his family's fortune (which was one of the largest fortunes of the 19th century) in [[mining]] and [[smelting]]. Guggenheim invested in silver mines of the [[Leadville mining district]] of [[Colorado]]. From mining he expanded into ore smelting, also in Colorado, then built a number of smelters across the US and in northern Mexico. As his sons grew up, they took leading roles in the family mining and smelting business.National Mining Hall of Fame, [http://www.mininghalloffame.org/inductee.asp?i=32&b=inductees%2Easp&t=n&p=G&s= Meyer Guggenheim], accessed 13 January 2014 ==Personal life== Guggenheim and his wife Barbara had ten surviving children. Five of his seven sons were active in the family businesses: *[[Isaac Guggenheim]] (1854–1922) *[[Daniel Guggenheim]] (1856–1930), head of the family after his father's death, who was the most active of his sons in developing and acquiring worldwide mining interests *[[Murry Guggenheim]] (1858–1939), originally in the lace and embroidery import business and by 1881, involved in mining and smelting *[[Solomon R. Guggenheim|Solomon Robert Guggenheim]] (1861–1949), a supporter of [[modern art]] through [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation|his foundation]] and donations to the [[Museum of Modern Art]] *[[Simon Guggenheim|(John) Simon Guggenheim]] (1867–1941), a one-term [[United States Senate|senator]] from [[Colorado]] *[[Benjamin Guggenheim]] (1865–1912), who died in the [[RMS Titanic|''Titanic'']] disaster *[[William Guggenheim]] *Jeanette Guggenheim *Rose Guggenheim *Cora Guggenheim Rothschild (married to Louis Frank Rothschild, founder of [[L.F. Rothschild]]) == See also == *[[Peggy Guggenheim]], daughter of Benjamin Guggenheim ==References== {{reflist|refs= {{cite web |url = http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/248426/Meyer-Guggenheim |title = Meyer Guggenheim |work = Encyclopedia |publisher = [[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate = 2013-04-05 }} }} ==External links== * [http://www.mininghalloffame.org/inductee.asp?i=32&b=inductees%2Easp&t=n&p=G&s= National Mining Hall of Fame: ''Meyer Guggenheim''] {{DEFAULTSORT:Guggenheim, Meyer}} [[Category:1828 births]] [[Category:1905 deaths]] [[Category:People from Zurzach District]] [[Category:Swiss Jews]] [[Category:19th-century American businesspeople]] [[Category:American people of German-Jewish descent]] [[Category:American people of Swiss-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Businesspeople in metals]] [[Category:American mining businesspeople]] [[Category:Guggenheim family|Meyer Guggenheim]] [[Category:Swiss emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Burials at Salem Fields Cemetery, Brooklyn]] {{US-business-bio-1820s-stub}}

{{Infobox person |name = Othman Benjelloun |image = |caption = Othman Benjelloun <small>(January 2012)</small> |birth_date = {{birth year and age|1931}} |birth_place = [[Fez]], Morocco |death_date = |death_place = |death_cause = |resting_place = |residence = Morocco |nationality = Moroccan |known_for = Being a bank owner and an insurance firm owner |occupation = Businessman | networth = US$1.67 billion (February 2018)<ref name="Forbes profile">{{cite web|title=Forbes profile: Othman Benjelloun|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/othman-benjelloun/|website=Forbes|accessdate=14 February 2018}}</ref> | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | boards = | spouse = {{Marriage|[[Leïla Mezian Benjelloun|Leïla Mezian]]|1960}} | children = Kamal & Dounia | parents = | relatives = | website = }}
'''Othman Benjelloun''' ({{lang-ar|عثمان بن جلون}}; born 1931 in [[Fez]], Morocco) is a Moroccan [[Arabs|Arab]] [[businessperson|businessman]]. In 2018, Othman Benjelloun ranked #1477 on the ''Forbes'' World's Billionaires list, with wealth listed at US $1.6 billion.<ref>https://www.forbes.com/billionaires/list/3/#version:static_header:source</ref>
==Career== Benjelloun's father was a large shareholder in an [[insurance]] company that Othman later took over in 1988. He turned this into [[RMA Watanya]].<ref name="othman">[http://www.therichest.org/nation/richest-people-in-africa-2011/ ''Othman Benjelloun''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120116125009/http://www.therichest.org/nation/richest-people-in-africa-2011/ |date=2012-01-16 }} career information at TheRichest.org</ref> After purchasing the insurance company, Benjelloun expanded the business venture into the [[banking]] industry.<ref name="othman"/> His banking enterprise, the [[BMCE Bank]] has its presence felt in at least 12 countries in Africa after it purchased the [[Mali]]-based [[Bank of Africa]].<ref name="othman"/> The banking aspect of Benjelloun's business career is worth $4 billion based solely on its [[market capitalization]] profits.<ref name="othman"/>
Othman received an education in engineering at the [[École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne]] in Switzerland.<ref name="sb">[http://www.silobreaker.com/biography-for-othman-benjelloun-5_2260566016436207616_4 ''Othman Benjelloun''] biography at Silobreaker</ref> During the 1960s and 1970s, Othman would make strategic alliances with global automobile manufacturers [[Volvo]] and [[General Motors]]. He is also the chairman of [[Méditel|Meditelecom]] along with being associated with [[Telefónica]] and [[Portugal Telecom]].<ref name="sb"/> Benjelloun is a member of the [[World Union of Arab Bankers]].<ref name="sb"/>
He net was worth $2.2 billion as of October 2015, making him 3rd richest man in his country, and the 13th richest in Africa.<ref name="Forbes profile"/>
==Personal life== He is married to Leila Mezian, daughter of the Moroccan General [[Mohamed Meziane]], with whom he has two children.<ref name="Forbes profile"/>
==See also== * [[Economy of Morocco]]
