{{About|the trade surpluses of oil-exporting nations|a broader term with multiple meanings|Petrocurrency}} {{good article}} {{Use mdy dates|date=February 2016}} [[File:Opecrev.gif|thumb|alt=refer to caption|Fluctuations of OPEC net oil export revenues since 1972, showing elevated inflation-adjusted levels during 1974–1981 and 2005–2014<ref name=EIA2006>{{cite web|url=http://www.eia.doe.gov/emeu/cabs/OPEC_Revenues/OPEC.html |title=OPEC Revenues Fact Sheet |publisher=[[U.S. Energy Information Administration]] |date=January 10, 2006 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080107014809/http://www.eia.doe.gov/emeu/cabs/OPEC_Revenues/OPEC.html |archivedate=January 7, 2008 }}</ref><ref name=EIA2015/>]]
'''Petrodollar recycling''' is the international spending or investment of a country's revenues from [[petroleum]] exports ("'''petrodollars'''"). It generally refers to the phenomenon of major [[List of countries by oil exports|petroleum-exporting nations]], mainly the [[OPEC#Membership|OPEC members]] plus [[Russia]] and [[Norway]], earning more money from the export of crude oil than they could efficiently invest in their own economies. The resulting global interdependencies and financial flows, from oil producers back to oil consumers, can reach a scale of hundreds of billions of [[US dollars]] per year – including a wide range of transactions in a variety of currencies, some [[Currency peg|pegged]] to the US dollar and some not. These flows are heavily influenced by government-level decisions regarding international investment and aid, with important consequences for both [[global finance]] and [[petroleum politics]]. The phenomenon is most pronounced during periods when the [[price of oil]] is historically high.<ref>{{cite web |last=Nsouli |first=Saleh M. |title=Petrodollar Recycling and Global Imbalances |url=http://www.imf.org/en/news/articles/2015/09/28/04/53/sp032306a |publisher=[[International Monetary Fund]] |date=March 23, 2006 |accessdate=January 14, 2017}}</ref>
The term petrodollar was coined in the early 1970s during the [[OPEC oil crisis|oil crisis]], and the first major petrodollar surge (1974–1981) resulted in more financial complications than the second (2005–2014).<ref name="kinzer">{{cite book |last1=Kinzer |first1=Stephen |title=All the Shah's Men: An American Coup and the Roots of Middle East Terror |publisher=Wiley |isbn=047018549X |accessdate=19 October 2018}}</ref>
In August 2018, [[Venezuela]] declared that it would price its oil in [[Euros]], [[Yuan (currency)|Yuan]] and other currencies.<ref name="ven">{{cite news |title=US dollars no longer a quote currency in Venezuela |url=http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-10/18/c_137540829.htm |accessdate=19 October 2018 |publisher=Xinhua Net |date=18 October 2018}}</ref>
==Capital flows==
===Background=== Especially during the years [[1970s energy crisis|1974–1981]] and [[2000s energy crisis|2005–2014]], oil exporters amassed large surpluses of "petrodollars" from historically expensive oil.<ref name=EIA2006/><ref name=EIA2015>{{cite web |url=http://www.eia.gov/beta/international/regions-topics.cfm?RegionTopicID=OPEC |title=OPEC Revenues Fact Sheet |publisher=U.S. Energy Information Administration |date=May 15, 2017 |accessdate=May 28, 2017}}</ref><ref name=profusion>{{cite news |url=http://www.economist.com/node/21553424 |title=Petrodollar Profusion |newspaper=[[The Economist]] |date=April 28, 2012 |accessdate=February 7, 2016}}</ref> (The word has been credited alternately to Egyptian-American economist [[Ibrahim Oweiss]] and to former [[US Secretary of Commerce]] [[Peter G. Peterson]], both in 1973.)<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.wrmea.org/1983-december-26/personality-ibrahim-m.-oweiss.html |title=Personality: Ibrahim M. Oweiss |journal=Washington Report on Middle East Affairs |date=December 26, 1983 |accessdate=January 11, 2017 |page=8 |quote=In March 1973... Two weeks after Dr. Oweiss had used the word – at an international monetary seminar held at Columbia University's Arden House in Harriman, New York – it was picked up by a prestigious economics commentator in ''The New York Times''.}} According to the [http://faculty.georgetown.edu/imo3/petrod/petro2.htm Oweiss] and [https://www.nytimes.com/1974/03/13/archives/the-petrodollar-flow-if-the-panglossian-economic-theory-is-rightand.html NYT] websites, it appears that these events actually occurred in March 1974.</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost_historical/doc/148405620.html |title=Peterson Urges Cooperation |first=Hobart |last=Rowen |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=July 9, 1973 |accessdate=February 5, 2016 |page=A1 |quote=He thinks the U.S. should give more study to ways in which the excess funds – he calls them petro dollars – can be soaked up.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.barrypopik.com/index.php/new_york_city/entry/petrodollar |title=Petrodollar |first=Barry |last=Popik |authorlink=Barry Popik |date=February 1, 2012 |accessdate=January 11, 2017 |quote=Georgetown University economics professor Ibrahim Oweiss has written about petrodollars and is credited with the word's coinage by Wikipedia, but there is insufficient documentary evidence that he used the term first in 1973. Former commerce secretary Peter G. Peterson was credited with using 'petrodollar' in a July 1973 ''Washington Post'' article.}}</ref> These petrodollar surpluses could be described as net US dollar-equivalents earned from the export of petroleum, in excess of the internal development needs of the exporting nations.<ref name=Oweiss/> The surpluses could not be efficiently invested in their own economies, due to small populations or being at early stages of [[industrialization]]; but the surpluses could be usefully invested in other nations, or spent on imports such as consumer products, construction supplies, and military equipment. Alternatively, global economic growth would have suffered if that money was withdrawn from the world economy, while the oil-exporting nations needed to be able to invest profitably to raise their long-term standards of living.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.imf.org/external/np/exr/center/mm/eng/mm_rs_03.htm |title=Petrodollar Problem |publisher=International Monetary Fund |accessdate=January 31, 2016}}</ref>
===1974–1981 surge=== While petrodollar recycling reduced the short-term [[1973–75 recession|recessionary]] impact of the [[1973 oil crisis]], it caused problems especially for oil-importing countries that were paying much higher prices for oil, and incurring long-term debts. The [[International Monetary Fund]] (IMF) estimated that the foreign debts of 100 oil-importing [[developing countries]] increased by 150% between 1973 and 1977, complicated further by a worldwide shift to [[floating exchange rate]]s. [[Johan Witteveen]], the Managing Director of the IMF, said in 1974: "The international monetary system is facing its most difficult period since the 1930s."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.imf.org/external/np/exr/center/mm/eng/rs_sub_3.htm |title=Recycling Petrodollars |publisher=International Monetary Fund |accessdate=January 31, 2016}}</ref> The IMF administered a new lending program during 1974–1976 called the Oil Facility. Funded by oil-exporting nations and other lenders, it was available to nations suffering from acute problems with their [[balance of trade]] due to the rise in oil prices, notably including [[Italy]] and the [[UK]] as well as dozens of developing countries.<ref>{{cite web |title=International Balance of Payments Financing and the Budget Process |publisher=[[U.S. Congressional Budget Office]] |first=Carl Richard |last=Neu |date=August 1977 |pages=27–29 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VK6wuXHuPJkC&pg=PA27 |accessdate=February 5, 2016}}</ref>
From 1974 through 1981, the total [[current account]] surplus for all members of OPEC amounted to US$450 billion, without scaling-up for the subsequent decades of inflation. Ninety percent of this surplus was accumulated by the [[Arab countries]] of the [[Persian Gulf]] and [[Libya]], with [[Iran]] also accumulating significant oil surpluses through 1978 before suffering the hardships of [[Iranian Revolution|revolution]], [[Iran–Iraq War|war]] and [[Sanctions against Iran|sanctions]].<ref name=Oweiss>{{cite book |chapterurl=http://faculty.georgetown.edu/imo3/petrod/petro2.htm |chapter=Economics of Petrodollars |title=The Economic Dimensions of Middle Eastern History |pages=179–199 |authorlink=Ibrahim Oweiss |first=Ibrahim M. |last=Oweiss |editor-first1=Haleh |editor-last1=Esfandiari |editor-first2=A.L. |editor-last2=Udovitch |publisher=Darwin Press |date=1990 |accessdate=January 31, 2016}}</ref>
Large volumes of Arab petrodollars were invested directly in [[US Treasury securities]] and in other financial markets of the major industrial economies, often directed discreetly by government entities now known as [[sovereign wealth funds]].<ref>{{cite book |first=David E. |last=Spiro |title=The Hidden Hand of American Hegemony: Petrodollar Recycling and International Markets |location=Ithaca |publisher=[[Cornell University Press]] |date=1999 |isbn=0-8014-2884-X |pages=74–75 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=I3vWgRS_itIC&pg=PA74 |accessdate=February 8, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/features/2016-05-30/the-untold-story-behind-saudi-arabia-s-41-year-u-s-debt-secret |title=The Untold Story Behind Saudi Arabia's 41-Year U.S. Debt Secret |first=Andrea |last=Wong |publisher=[[Bloomberg News]] |date=May 30, 2016 |accessdate=May 31, 2016}}</ref> Many billions of petrodollars were also invested through the major [[commercial bank]]s of the US and Europe. In fact, the process contributed to the growth of the [[Eurodollar]] market as a less-regulated rival to US monetary markets. As the recessionary condition of the world economy made investment in corporations less attractive, bankers and well-financed governments lent much of the money directly to the governments of developing countries, especially in Latin America such as [[Economy of Brazil|Brazil]] and [[Economy of Argentina|Argentina]]<ref name=Oweiss/> as well as other major developing nations like [[Turkey]]. The 1973 oil crisis had created a vast dollar shortage in these countries; however, they still needed to finance their imports of oil and machinery. In early 1977, when Turkey stopped heating its prime minister's office, opposition leader [[Suleyman Demirel]] famously described the shortage as: "Turkey is in need of 70 cents."<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OY09BAAAQBAJ&pg=PA34 |title=State–Business Alliances and Economic Development: Turkey, Mexico and North Africa |first=Işık |last=Özel |publisher=[[Routledge]] |date=2014 |isbn=978-1-317-81782-6 |page=34 |accessdate=January 31, 2016}}</ref> As political journalist [[William Greider]] summarized the situation: "Banks collected the deposits of revenue-rich OPEC governments and lent the money to developing nations so they could avoid bankruptcy."<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lFWuAAAAIAAJ&q=revenue-rich |first=William |last=Greider |authorlink=William Greider |title=Secrets of the Temple |publisher=[[Simon & Schuster]] |date=1987 |isbn=978-0-671-47989-3 |page=340 |accessdate=January 31, 2016}}</ref> In subsequent decades, many of these developing nations found their [[Latin American debt crisis|accumulated debts]] to be [[Unpayable debt|unpayably large]], concluding that it was a form of [[neocolonialism]] from which [[debt relief]] was the only escape.<ref>{{cite book |chapterurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606040838/http://www.uiowa.edu/ifdebook/ebook2/contents/part4-I.shtml |chapter=Foreign Debt: Forgiveness and Repudiation |url=http://www.uiowa.edu/ifdebook/ebook2/ebook.shtml |title=The E-Book on International Finance & Development |first1=Enrique |last1=Carrasco |first2=Charles |last2=McClellan |first3=Jane |last3=Ro |publisher=[[University of Iowa]] |date=April 2007 |accessdate=June 6, 2011 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606000610/http://www.uiowa.edu/ifdebook/ebook2/ebook.shtml |archivedate=June 6, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
===2005–2014 surge=== [[File:InflationAndInterestRates.png|thumb|alt=refer to caption|Inflation and interest rates surged with oil prices in the 1970s, but not in the 2000s.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://fred.stlouisfed.org/graph/?graph_id=239792 |title=Federal Reserve Economic Data graph |publisher=[[Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis]] |accessdate=August 25, 2016}}</ref>]]
In the 2005–2014 petrodollar surge, financial decision-makers were able to benefit somewhat from the lessons and experiences of the previous cycle. Developing economies generally stayed better balanced than they did in the 1970s; the world economy was less oil-intensive; and global inflation and interest rates were much better contained. Oil exporters opted to make most of their investments directly into a diverse array of global markets, and the recycling process was less dependent on intermediary channels such as international banks and the IMF.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.un.org/esa/ffd/events/2007debtworkshop/david%20lubin.pdf |title=Petrodollars, emerging markets and vulnerability |first=David |last=Lubin |publisher=[[Citigroup]] |date=March 19, 2007 |accessdate=January 31, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.economist.com/node/5136281 |title=Recycling the Petrodollars |newspaper=The Economist |date=November 10, 2005 |accessdate=February 14, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/2008/08/08/oil-liquidity-petrodollars-biz_0811oxford.html |title=World Economy Less Vulnerable To Petrodollars |author=Oxford Analytica |date=August 11, 2008 |accessdate=January 13, 2017}}</ref>
Thanks to the historic [[oil price increases of 2003–2008]], OPEC revenues approximated an unprecedented US$1 trillion per year in 2008 and 2011–2014.<ref name=EIA2015/> Beyond the OPEC countries, substantial surpluses also accrued to Russia and Norway,<ref name=profusion/> and sovereign wealth funds worldwide amassed US$7 trillion by 2014–2015.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-02-22/sovereign-wealth-funds-seen-selling-404-billion-of-equities |title=Sovereign Wealth Funds May Sell $404 Billion of Equities |first=Stefania |last=Bianchi |publisher=Bloomberg News |date=February 22, 2016 |accessdate=February 22, 2016}}</ref> Some oil exporters were unable to reap the full benefits, as the national economies of Iran, Iraq, Libya, Nigeria and Venezuela all suffered from multi-year political obstacles associated with what economists call the "[[resource curse]]".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.resourcegovernance.org/sites/default/files/nrgi_Resource-Curse.pdf |title=The Resource Curse |publisher=Natural Resource Governance Institute |date=March 2015 |accessdate=January 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=d7vbCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT87&lpg=PT89 |title=The Price of Oil |first1=Roberto F. |last1=Aguilera |first2=Marian |last2=Radetzki |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=2015 |isbn=978-1-31643242-6 |pages=87–89 |accessdate=January 22, 2017}}</ref> Most of the other large exporters accumulated enough financial reserves to cushion the shock when oil prices and petrodollar surpluses fell sharply again from an [[2010s oil glut|oil supply glut in 2014–2017]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-04-13/oil-rich-nations-burn-through-petrodollar-assets-at-record-pace |title=Oil-Rich Nations Are Selling Off Their Petrodollar Assets at Record Pace |first=Javier |last=Blas |publisher=Bloomberg News |date=April 13, 2015 |accessdate=February 14, 2016}}</ref>
==Foreign aid== Oil-exporting countries have used part of their petrodollar surpluses to fund [[foreign aid]] programs, as a prominent example of so-called "[[checkbook diplomacy]]" or "[[petro-Islam]]". The [[Kuwait Fund]] was an early leader since 1961, and certain Arab nations became some of the largest donors in the years since 1974, including through the IMF and the [[OPEC Fund for International Development]].<ref name=Oweiss/><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.kuwait-fund.org/timeLine/?lang=en |title=Timeline |publisher=Kuwait Fund |accessdate=January 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/21/world/middleeast/cables-released-by-wikileaks-reveal-saudis-checkbook-diplomacy.html |title=Cables Released by WikiLeaks Reveal Saudis' Checkbook Diplomacy |first=Ben |last=Hubbard |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=June 21, 2015 |accessdate=February 16, 2016}}</ref> Oil exporters have also aided poorer nations indirectly through the personal [[remittances]] sent home by tens of millions of [[Foreign worker#Foreign workers in Middle East|foreign workers in the Middle East]],<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/gadfly/articles/2016-02-04/oil-s-plunge-spills-over |title=Oil's Plunge Spills Over |first=Andy |last=Mukherjee |publisher=Bloomberg News |date=February 4, 2016 |accessdate=February 4, 2016}}</ref> although their working conditions are generally harsh.<ref name=migrants/> Even more controversially, several oil exporters have been major [[State-sponsored terrorism|financial supporters of armed groups]] challenging the governments of other countries.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/2008/10/27/iranian-general-tehran-arming-liberation-armies.html |title=Iranian General: Tehran Arming 'Liberation Armies' |date=October 27, 2008 |agency=[[Associated Press]] |accessdate=March 29, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Cbb_DQAAQBAJ&pg=PA207&lpg=PA208 |title=The Role of Terrorism in 21st-Century Warfare |first1=Leonard |last1=Weinberg |first2=Susanne |last2=Martin |publisher=Oxford University Press |date=2016 |isbn=978-1-78499764-9 |at="Libya", pp. 207–208 |accessdate=March 29, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/hillary-clinton-wikileaks-email-isis-saudi-arabia-qatar-us-allies-funding-barack-obama-knew-all-a7362071.html |title=US allies Saudi Arabia and Qatar are funding ISIS |first=Patrick |last=Cockburn |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |date=October 14, 2016 |accessdate=March 29, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Pacepa |first=Ion Mihai |authorlink=Ion Mihai Pacepa |title=Russian Footprints |url=http://www.nationalreview.com/articles/218533/russian-footprints/ion-mihai-pacepa |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150109232047/http://www.nationalreview.com/articles/218533/russian-footprints/ion-mihai-pacepa |archivedate=January 9, 2015 |deadurl=yes |journal=[[National Review]] |date=August 24, 2006}}</ref>
High-priced oil allowed the [[USSR]] to support the struggling economies of the [[Soviet bloc]] during the 1974–1981 petrodollar surge, and the loss of income during the [[1980s oil glut]] contributed to the bloc's collapse in 1989.<ref>{{cite web |title=The Economics Behind the Fall of the Berlin Wall |first=Ryan |last=McMaken |publisher=[[Mises Institute]] |date=November 7, 2014 |accessdate=January 12, 2016 |url=https://mises.org/library/economics-behind-fall-berlin-wall |quote=High oil prices in the 1970s propped up the regime so well, that had it not been for Soviet oil sales, it's quite possible the regime would have collapsed a decade earlier.}}</ref> During the 2005–2014 petrodollar surge, OPEC member [[Venezuela]] played a similar role supporting [[Cuba]] and [[Petrocaribe|other regional allies]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/4179050.stm |title=Venezuela ends upbeat Cuba visit |first=Stephen |last=Gibbs |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=August 24, 2005 |accessdate=November 28, 2016}}</ref> before the 2014–2017 oil downturn brought Venezuela to its own economic crisis.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-colombia-idUSKCN0ZX0V9 |title=Venezuelan shoppers flock across border to Colombia |first=Anggy |last=Polanco |agency=[[Reuters]] |date=July 17, 2016 |accessdate=December 31, 2016}}</ref>
==Gallery of notable examples== These images illustrate the diversity of major petrodollar recycling activities, in roughly chronological order: <gallery> File:1969 $100K Treasury Bill (front).jpg|[[US Treasury securities]], approximately $300 billion accumulated by [[OPEC#Membership|OPEC governments]] during 1960–2015<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ticdata.treasury.gov/Publish/mfhhis01.txt|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160103143348/http://ticdata.treasury.gov/Publish/mfhhis01.txt|title=Major Foreign Holders of Treasury Securities|publisher=[[U.S. Department of the Treasury]]|date=December 15, 2015|archivedate=January 3, 2016|deadurl=unfit}}</ref>|alt=refer to caption
File:60 Jahre Unimog - Wörth 2011 201 Produktion (5797901460).jpg|German vehicle factory for [[Daimler AG|Daimler]], whose largest consistent shareholder since 1974 has been [[Kuwait Investment Authority|Kuwait]]<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/kuwait-germany-investments-idUSL6N0RJ4CE20140918|title=Kuwait Investment Authority says to expand Germany investments|first=Edward|last=Taylor|agency=Reuters|date=September 18, 2014|accessdate=January 17, 2017|quote=The KIA... is the largest shareholder in Daimler.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kia.gov.kw/en/Speetches/MOF%20SPEECH-KIA%20DAIMLER%2040TH%20ANNIVERSARY%20(10.09.14).pdf|first=Anas K.|last=Al Saleh|title=KIA/Daimler 40th Anniversary Celebrations|publisher=[[Kuwait Investment Authority]]|date=September 18, 2014|accessdate=January 17, 2017|quote=From a 14.6% stake of around US$329 million acquisition in December 1974, the KIA is now the largest consistent shareholder in Daimler over 40 years where our 6.9% stake is currently valued around $7 billion.}}</ref>|alt=refer to caption
File:ItaipuAerea2AAL.jpg|[[Itaipu Dam]] between Brazil and Paraguay, financed by loans from petrodollar bank deposits in the 1970s<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3U-lvpSO4RQC&pg=PA202|title=Brazil Is Not for Amateurs|author=[[:pt:Belmiro Valverde Jobim Castor|Castor, Belmiro V.J.]]|edition=English, 2nd|publisher=[[Xlibris]]|year=2003|isbn=978-1-46910432-4|page=202|accessdate=January 18, 2017|quote=International bankers... began to invest huge amounts of those petro-dollars in Brazil and other developing countries..., allowing them to finance gigantic infrastructure works like the Itaipu Hydroelectric Plant.}}</ref>{{Self-published inline|certain=yes|date=December 2017}}|alt=refer to caption
File:FaisalMasjid.jpg|Pakistan's [[Faisal Mosque]], constructed 1976–1986, a gift from Saudi Arabia's [[Faisal of Saudi Arabia|King Faisal]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lonelyplanet.com/pakistan/islamabad-rawalpindi/attractions/shah-faisal-mosque/a/poi-sig/464356/357196|title=Shah Faisal Mosque|publisher=Lonely Planet|accessdate=March 29, 2017|quote=Most of its cost (pegged at about US$120 million today) was a gift from King Faisal of Saudi Arabia.}}</ref>|alt=refer to caption
File:Wheat sacks in a Portland, Oregon warehouse (3718620966).jpg|Western grain, heavily imported by the [[Soviet Union]] to ease food shortages in the 1970s and 1980s<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xjTVBAAAQBAJ&pg=PT109&lpg=PT110|chapter=Soviet foreign policy from détente to Gorbachev, 1975–1985|first=Vyadislav M.|last=Zubok|title=The Cambridge History of the Cold War: Volume III, Endings|editor1-first=Melvyn P.|editor1-last=Leffler|editor2-first=Odd Arne|editor2-last=Westad|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2010|isbn=978-1-31602563-5|pages=109–110|accessdate=January 18, 2017|quote=The former head of the Soviet planning agency, Nikolai Baibakov, recalled that 'what we got for oil and gas' was $15 billion in 1976–80 and $35 billion in 1981–85. Of this money, the Soviets spent, respectively, $14 billion and $26.3 billion to buy grain, both to feed the cattle on collective farms and to put bread on the tables of Soviet citizens.}}</ref>|alt=refer to caption
File:Saudi F-15.JPEG|American-built [[F-15]] fighter jet, one of dozens owned by the [[Royal Saudi Air Force]] since 1981<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/22/world/saudi-awacs-deal-passes-8-billion.html|title=Saudi AWACS Deal Passes $8 Billion|first=Charles|last=Mohr|newspaper=The New York Times|date=August 22, 1981|accessdate=November 5, 2016|quote=The price of the arms sale gives increased weight to an argument that in part it should be approved because it helps to 'recycle petrodollars'.}}</ref>|alt=refer to caption
File:Harrods at Night, London - Nov 2012.jpg|[[Harrods]] department store in London, under Arab ownership since 1985<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/09/08/business/harrod-s-new-owner-mohamed-al-fayed-a-quiet-acquisitor-is-caught-in-a-cross-fire.html?pagewanted=all|title=Harrod's New Owner: Mohamed al-Fayed; A Quiet Acquisitor Is Caught in a Cross Fire|first=Barnaby J.|last=Feder|newspaper=The New York Times|date=September 8, 1985|accessdate=January 16, 2017|quote=This was a dream come true for the family, which built its fortune... first in the oil-rich countries of the Persian Gulf.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/8669657.stm|title=Mohammed Fayed sells Harrods store to Qatar Holdings|publisher=BBC|date=May 8, 2010|accessdate=February 7, 2016}}</ref>|alt=refer to caption
File:Stamford Bridge - West Stand.jpg|London's [[Chelsea Football Club]], Russian-owned since 2003 through the [[Sibneft]] oil fortune<ref>{{cite news|title=Russian businessman buys Chelsea|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/3036838.stm|publisher=BBC|date=July 2, 2003|accessdate=March 23, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Roman Abramovich reaches 700 games as Chelsea owner – but how does his reign stack up against the rest?|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/roman-abramovich-reaches-700-games-as-chelsea-owner-but-how-does-his-reign-stack-up-against-the-rest-10171465.html|first=Mark|last=Critchley|newspaper=The Independent|date=April 12, 2015|accessdate=August 1, 2016|quote=Since the Russian oligarch began pouring petro-dollars into Stamford Bridge, he has turned one of English football's underachieving clubs into an established powerhouse.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=The colossal wealth of Manchester City and Chelsea is changing the landscape of British football|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/manchester-city-vs-chelsea-colossal-3104678|first=Miguel|last=Delaney|newspaper=[[The Sunday Mirror]]|date=February 2, 2014|accessdate=August 1, 2016|quote=It should not escape notice that this is the first true title showdown, and first genuine title race, between the petrodollar clubs.}}</ref>|alt=refer to caption

As many as 30,000 Cubans in Venezuela are presumably medical doctors.}}</ref>|alt=refer to caption
File:Bouteilles rangées by JM Rosier.jpg|Bottles of [[French wine#Quality levels and appellation system|premium French wine]], millions of which were purchased by Dubai-owned [[Emirates airline]] since 2005<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-01-05/how-emirates-airline-serves-the-best-wine-list-in-the-sky|title=Emirates Has Invested $500 Million to Build a 'Fort Knox' of Wine|first=James|last=Gaddy|publisher=Bloomberg News|date=January 5, 2017|accessdate=January 5, 2017|quote=Since the Dubai-based airline began its wine program 12 years ago, it has spent more than $500 million to develop the best wine list in the sky... 'It’s an investment. We look at it like a commodity.'}}</ref>|alt=refer to caption
File:Türk Telekom logo.svg|[[Türk Telekom|Turkish Telecom Corp.]], whose control was privatized to the [[Saudi Oger]] organization in 2005 with [[IMF]] support<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/oger-telecom-signs-655-bln-turk-telekom-deal.aspx?pageID=438&n=oger-telecom-signs-6.55-bln-turk-telekom-deal-2005-11-15|title=Oger Telecom signs $6.55 bln Turk Telekom deal|first=Hatice|last=Aydogdu|agency=Reuters|date=November 15, 2005|accessdate=January 30, 2017|quote='... a long-term investment, not only in the future of Turk Telekom but also in Turkey,' Hariri said. The sale of Turk Telekom's controlling stake is a key element of Turkey's IMF-backed privatization program.|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202053053/http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/oger-telecom-signs-655-bln-turk-telekom-deal.aspx?pageID=438&n=oger-telecom-signs-6.55-bln-turk-telekom-deal-2005-11-15|archivedate=February 2, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref>|alt=refer to caption
File:ChryslerBldgNYC2007.jpg|New York's [[Chrysler Building]], 90% owned by the [[Abu Dhabi Investment Council]] since 2008<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/09/business/worldbusiness/09iht-chrysler.4.14369327.html|title=Abu Dhabi buys 75% of Chrysler Building in latest trophy purchase|first1=Landon, Jr.|last1=Thomas|newspaper=The New York Times|date=July 9, 2008|quote=These funds, which maintain passive investment positions, will perform a crucial petrodollar-recycling function.|accessdate=December 29, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Charles V.|last=Bagli|date=July 10, 2008|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/10/nyregion/10chrysler.html|title=Abu Dhabi Buys 90% Stake in Chrysler Building|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=July 3, 2016}}</ref>|alt=refer to caption
File:Flickr - Israel Defense Forces - Missiles Found Aboard Francop.jpg|[[Funding of Hezbollah#Iran|Iranian weapon shipments]] to Lebanon and Syria, including [[Francop Affair|over 300 tons intercepted]] in 2009<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/12/10/AR2009121003608.html|title=U.N. panel voices concern over Iran's apparent violations of arms-export embargo|first=Colum|last=Lynch|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=December 11, 2009|accessdate=March 29, 2017|quote=A U.N. sanctions committee expressed 'grave concern' Thursday about what it called apparent Iranian violations of a U.N. ban on arms exports.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/iranian-official-admits-tehran-supplied-missiles-to-hezbollah-1.194408|title=Iranian Official Admits Tehran Supplied Missiles to Hezbollah|first1=Amos|last1=Harel|first2=Yoav|last2=Stern|newspaper=[[Haaretz]]|date=August 4, 2006|accessdate=March 29, 2017|quote=Mohtashami Pur, a one-time ambassador to Lebanon who currently holds the title of secretary-general of the 'Intifada conference', told an Iranian newspaper that Iran transferred the missiles to the Shi'ite militia.}}</ref>|alt=refer to caption
File:Card Players-Paul Cezanne.jpg|[[The Card Players|Cézanne painting]], purchased in 2011 by the [[Collecting practices of the Al-Thani Family|Royal Family of Qatar]] for a record-setting price above US$250 million<ref>{{cite news|last=Peers|first=Alexandra|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/culture/2012/02/qatar-buys-cezanne-card-players-201202|title=Qatar Purchases Cézanne's ''The Card Players'' for More Than $250 Million, Highest Price Ever for a Work of Art|journal=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]|date=February 2012|accessdate=February 19, 2016|quote=The money is there: the United Arab Emirates region is home to nearly 10 percent of all the world's oil reserve.}}</ref>|alt=refer to caption
File:CollageDubai.jpg|[[UAE]] construction boom during 2003–2014, primarily built by imported [[Foreign worker#Foreign workers in Middle East|foreign workers]] and contractors<ref name=migrants>{{cite journal|url=http://newleftreview.org/II/41/mike-davis-fear-and-money-in-dubai|title=Fear and Money in Dubai|first=Mike|last=Davis|journal=[[New Left Review]]|number=41|date=September–October 2006|accessdate=February 12, 2016|quote=Dubai is capitalized just as much on cheap labour as it is on expensive oil, and the Maktoums, like their cousins in the other emirates, are exquisitely aware that they reign over a kingdom built on the backs of a South Asian workforce.}}</ref>|alt=refer to caption
File:TOYOTA FJ's (3568773870) 3.jpg|[[Toyota]] vehicles in [[Kuwait]], where the Japanese automaker holds a dominant market share<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.just-auto.com/market-research/kuwait-autos-report-q2-2016_id254066.aspx|journal=Kuwait Autos Report|title=Q2 2016|date=March 2016|author=Business Monitor International|accessdate=January 13, 2017|quote=In 2015, Japanese carmaker Toyota retained its long-held local market leadership..., over three times its nearest rival Nissan.}}</ref>|alt=refer to caption </gallery>

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Orphan|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox person | image = | image_size = | name = Philippe Foriel-Destezet | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1935|09|12|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Lyon]], [[France]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | restingplace = | nationality = [[France|French]] | religion = | ethnicity = | residence = [[London]], [[England]] | education = | alma mater = [[HEC Paris]] | occupation = | known for = | salary = | networth = [[Pound sterling|GBP]] £1.75 billion (STRL, April 2015){{cite news|title=Sunday Times Rich List|work=The Sunday Times|issue=page 27|date=26 April 2014}}
[[United States dollar|US$]] 2.8 billion (Forbes, April 2015) | spouse = Aline Morel | parents = | children = 4 | relatives = | website = }} '''Philippe Foriel-Destezet''' (born 1935) is a French billionaire businessman. He owns 18% of the Swiss-based employment agency [[Adecco]], as well as a significant interest in AKILA Finance. ==Early life== He graduated from [[HEC Paris]] in 1958.{{cite web|title=Philippe Foriel-Destezet|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/philippe-foriel-destezet/|website=Forbes|accessdate=26 April 2015}} ==Career== He founded the employment agency Ecco in 1964. With Klaus Jacobs, he was instrumental in bringing about the merger of the French agency, Ecco and the Swiss agency, Adia Interim that created ''Adecco'' in 1996. He serves on the Boards of Adecco, [[AKILA Finance]] SA and [[Securitas]]. He stood down as co-chairman of Adecco in 2005, becoming honorary president in 2006. He is cited in the [[Panama Papers]] scandal in 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/panama-papers/article/2016/04/09/panama-papers-de-riches-francais-muets-sur-leurs-montages-offshore_4899119_4890278.html |title=" Panama papers " : de riches Français muets sur leurs montages offshore |publisher=Lemonde.fr |date=14 April 2017 |accessdate=17 June 2017}} ==Personal life== He is married to Aline. They live in London, and have four children. His daughter Alix is married to the French entrepreneur [[Mathieu Laine]]. ==See also== *[[List of billionaires]] *[[French Rich List]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.forbes.com/finance/lists/10/2004/LIR.jhtml?passListId=10&passYear=2004&passListType=Person&uniqueId=AVR0&datatype=Person Forbes.com: Forbes World's Richest People] {{DEFAULTSORT:Foriel-Destezet, Philippe}} [[Category:1935 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:French billionaires]] [[Category:French businesspeople]] [[Category:HEC Paris alumni]] [[Category:People from Lyon]] {{France-business-bio-stub}}

[[File:Carlos menem.jpg|thumb|right|150px|[[Carlos Menem]]'s administration carried out the privatisation process.]] '''Railway privatisation in Argentina''' was a process which began in 1993 under the presidency of [[Carlos Menem]], following a series of [[neoliberalism|neoliberal]] economic reforms. This primarily consisted of breaking-up the state-owned railway company [[Ferrocarriles Argentinos]] (FA) and allowing the former lines to be operated by private companies instead of the state. This policy was met with widespread criticism and proved catastrophic for the Argentine railways whose service worsened significantly in the years that followed, with entire lines closing and infrastructure deteriorating beyond repair.<ref name=monografias>[http://www.monografias.com/trabajos916/sistema-ferroviario-argentino/sistema-ferroviario-argentino2.shtml El servicio ferroviario argentino de las últimas dos décadas, el antes y después de las privatizaciones] - Monografias.com</ref><ref name=sabrinaramirez>[https://sabrinaramirez.wordpress.com/2013/07/24/privatizacion-de-los-ferrocarriles-argentinos-ramal-que-para-ramal-que-cierra/ Privatización de los ferrocarriles: “Ramal que para, ramal que cierra”] - Contra Molinos de Sortilegios, 24 July 2013</ref><ref name=ancaloo>[http://www.ancaloo.com.ar/nota/3246/como-perdimos-el-ferrocarril-argentino COMO PERDIMOS EL FERROCARRIL ARGENTINO] - Ancaloo, 29 September 2008</ref> Privatisation was ultimately reversed in 2015 with the creation of [[Nuevos Ferrocarriles Argentinos]].<ref>[http://www.ambito.com/noticia.asp?id=786700 "Senado convirtió en ley estatización de trenes"], ''Ambito Financiero'', 16 Apr 2015</ref><ref name=cron>[http://www.cronista.com/economiapolitica/Con-solo-dos-votos-en-contra-el-Senado-sanciono-la-ley-de-estatizacion-de-los-trenes-20150416-0053.html "Con sólo dos votos en contra, el Senado sancionó la ley de estatización de los trenes"], Cronista.com, 16 Apr 2015</ref>
==Background== [[File:Ferrocarriles Argentinos - Cruzada en Marcos Paz.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Domingo Sarmiento Railway|Sarmiento Railway]] rolling stock during the FA era.]] Since railway nationalisation in 1948, during the presidency of [[Juan Perón]], the network had been operated by the state-owned company [[Ferrocarriles Argentinos]] (FA) which comprised the six relatively independent divisions, [[Domingo Sarmiento Railway|Sarmiento]], [[General Bartolomé Mitre Railway|Mitre]], [[General Urquiza Railway|Urquiza]], [[General San Martín Railway|San Martín]], [[General Belgrano Railway|Belgrano]] and [[General Roca Railway|Roca]].
By the time that President [[Carlos Menem]]'s administration took over the Government in 1989 FA had a serious economic deficit, with no investment projected and a high amount of social charges owed to the state. The amount of [[rail freight transport|freight]] services had considerably decreased between 1970 and 1990, going from 13,500 million of tons to 7,500 millions twenty years after (almost a 55%). The infrastructure and rolling stock were seriously deteriorated, with the exception of central network. Most part of locomotives and coaches had become obsolete therefore the costs of mainteanance had also increased. The aim was to reduce FA's deficit previous to a major restructuring of the company.
With the railway network's chronic deficit having risen to USD 355 million per year (about USD 1 million per day), the [[Congress of Argentina|National Congress]] adopted Law 23,696 (named "Ley de Reforma del Estado") that began the privatisation process in 1989.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20131101235034/http://infoleg.mecon.gov.ar/infolegInternet/anexos/0-4999/98/texact.htm Ley 23.696 - Emergencia Administrativa. Privatizaciones y Participación del Capital Privado] on Infoleg, promulgated 18 Ago 1989</ref>
The Law allowed president Menem to declare a state of emergency over any state-owned company with the objective to proceed to a privatisation or closure of that company. In November 1989, Menem pronounced his famous threat to any railworkers contemplating strike action: ''"Ramal que para, ramal que cierra"'' ("A line that goes on strike is a line that will be shut").<ref>[http://edant.clarin.com/diario/1997/05/25/i-01602e.htm "Ramal que cierra, pueblo que muere"], ''Clarín'', 25 May 1997</ref><ref>[http://www.pagina12.com.ar/diario/elpais/1-243065-2014-03-31.html "De la resistencia a la recuperación"], ''Página/12'', 31 Mar 2014</ref>
== Freight Services == [[File:Locomotive Brian 8118.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Ferrosur Roca]] was granted [[General Roca Railway|Roca Railway]].]] [[File:NCA EVC mayo 2011.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Nuevo Central Argentino]] took over [[General Bartolomé Mitre Railway|Mitre Railway]].]] [[File:Ferroexpreso Pampeano 2.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Ferroexpreso Pampeano]] operated [[Domingo Sarmiento Railway|Sarmiento Railway]].]] [[File:G22U 4365 ALL.JPG|thumb|right|200px|[[América Latina Logística]] worked on Urquiza and San Martín networks.]]
Although FA supported the idea of operating the freight line competing with private companies, the Ministry of Public Works (assisted by the World Bank) excluded FA from the activity, allowing only private concessionaires to operate the lines. In 1990 a program of restructuring was signed by FA, the Ministry and the World Bank. That agreement was the first official document to suggest the possibility to exclude FA from the opearation of public transport.<ref>[http://siteresources.worldbank.org/INTRAILWAYS/Resources/b35.pdf "Best Methods of Railway Restructuring and Privatization" by Ron Kopicki & Louis S. Thompson], CFS Discussion Paper Series n° 111 - World Bank website</ref>
The government granted concessions for a term of 30 years, extensible to 10 years else. It was also established that investments made by private operators became property of the state when the contract of concession finished. The concessionaire only kept the rolling stock or other goods acquired during the term of concession.
For freight transport, the government established zones of interest according to traffic. The first section was [[Rosario, Santa Fe|Rosario]]–[[Bahía Blanca]] with a traffic estimated in 2,000,000 tones carried by year along its 5,300-km length. The second section was the Urquiza Railway with 1,200,000 ton per year along 2,700-km length. The third section was Mitre Railway with 2,500,000 tons (also considering the possibility of passenger services) in its 4,800-km length. The San Martín Railway was included as the fourth section, with 4,700-km length
Most part of Roca Railway was granted in concession to [[Ferrosur Roca]], property of [[Loma Negra]], the largest cement producer of Argentina. The San Martín was granted to [[Buenos Aires al Pacífico S.A.]] while Sarmiento was granted to [[Ferroexpreso Pampeano]] (owned by [[Techint]]), Urquiza to Ferrocarril Mesopotámico and Mitre to [[Nuevo Central Argentino]].
Only the Belgrano Railway freight service remained under the control of the state due to lack of interest from private inversors. Nevertheless, the railway would be granted to [[Belgrano Cargas]] S.A., a consortium established by railway union "Unión Ferroviaria" in 1999. That same year, [[Brazil]]ian company [[América Latina Logística]] (ALL) took over the Urquiza and San Martín lines replacing Ferrocarril Mesopotámico and BAP respectively.
Freight services were granted in concession as follows:<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20111223093724/http://www.cnrt.gov.ar/infoferro/espanol/data/historia_data.htm#priv "La concesión del sistema ferroviario de Cargas" - Historia de los Ferrocarriles Argentinos], CNRT website (Archive), 23 Dec 2011</ref>
{| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:left" | colspan="5" style= "background: #cccccc; color: #00000" | <center> '''Freight services privatisation'''</center> |- ! width=250px| Concessionaire ! width=170px| Railway/s ! width=60px| Gauge (mm) ! width=60px| Length (km) ! width=100px| Period |- | [[Ferroexpreso Pampeano]]|| [[Domingo Sarmiento Railway|Sarmiento]], [[General Roca Railway|Roca]]<sup>1</sup> || 1,676 ||5,094|| 1991–present |- | [[Nuevo Central Argentino]] || [[General Bartolomé Mitre Railway|Mitre]] || 1,676 ||4,900|| 1992–present |- | [[Ferrosur Roca]] || [[General Roca Railway|Roca]] || 1,676 ||3,145|| 1993–present |- | [[Buenos Aires al Pacífico S.A.|Buenos Aires al Pacifíco]] <sup>2</sup> || [[General San Martín Railway|San Martín]] ||1,676|| 5,690|| 1993-1999 |- | Mesopotámico General Urquiza || [[General Urquiza Railway|Urquiza]] ||1,435||2,704|| 1993-1999 |- | rowspan=2| [[América Latina Logística]] || [[General Urquiza Railway|Urquiza]] || 1,435 || 2,704 || 1999-2013 |- | [[General San Martín Railway|San Martín]] ||1,676|| 5,690|| 1999-2013 |- | [[Belgrano Cargas]] <sup>2</sup>|| [[General Belgrano Railway|Belgrano]] || 1,000 ||9,860|| 1999-2013 |}
'''Notes:''' * <sup>1</sup> ''Only the [[Rosario and Puerto Belgrano Railway|Rosario and Puerto Belgrano]] line.''<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20111217152628/http://www.cnrt.gov.ar/infoferro/espanol/data/cargas/d_fepsa_mapa.htm "Mapa de la red - FEPSA"], CNRT website (Archive)</ref> * <sup>2</sup> ''Not to be confused with the [[Great Britain|British]]-owned company [[Buenos Aires and Pacific Railway]], the original concessionary and builder of the line that had been awarded concession in 1872.<ref>''British Railways in Argentina 1857-1914: A Case Study of Foreign Investment'' by Colin M. Lewis - Athlone Press (for the Institute of Latin American Studies, University of London, 1983)</ref> * <sup>2</sup> ''Took over by state-owned [[Trenes Argentinos Cargas y Logística|Belgrano Cargas y Logística]] in 2013.''
== Passenger services ==
=== Commuter rail (Buenos Aires) === [[File:EMD GT22CW locomotive (A903) - 01.jpg|thumb|right|200px|A [[Metropolitano]] train in La Plata.]] [[File:Estación Colegiales Ferrocarril Mitre 2.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Trenes de Buenos Aires|TBA]] operated Mitre and Sarmiento lines.]] [[File:Tren de grand bourg.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Ferrovías]] train at Grand Bourg.]] [[File:Coche 2 Linea D Subte.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Buenos Aires Underground]] unit.]] [[File:Argentine train - Ferrocentral - Buenos Aires - Tucuman.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Ferrocentral]] ran trains to Tucumán.]] [[File:Estación Cassaffousth.JPG|thumb|right|200px|[[Tren de las Sierras]] served by Ferrocentral.]] [[File:Provincia de Buenos Aires - Dolores - Estación.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Ferrobaires]] was created by the government of Buenos Aires.]] [[File:Garratt L D Porta frontal.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The [[Southern Fuegian Railway]] was revived in 1994.]]
In March 1991 the government separated the urban passenger rail services and metro operating within the city of Buenos Aires from the rest of the rail network, and to this end created the holding company [[FEMESA|Ferrocarriles Metropolitanos S.A. (FEMESA)]] whilst the freight concessionaires were expected to make a profit, it was recognized that the operation of these services would require public subsidy. Concessions were granted to the bidder who would require the lowest subsidy. Four companies bid successfully for the seven lines originally operated by the six divisions of [[Ferrocarriles Argentinos]], together with the [[Buenos Aires Underground|Subte]], as shown below:
{| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:left" | colspan="5" style= "background: #cccccc; color: #00000" | <center> '''Passenger services privatisation'''</center> |- ! width=250px| Concessionaire ! width=170px| Line/s ! width=60px| Gauge (mm) ! width=60px| Length (km) ! width=100px| Period |- | rowspan=2| [[Metrovías]]|| [[Urquiza Line|Urquiza]]|| 1,435||26|| 1994–present |- | [[Buenos Aires Underground|Subte]] || 1,435 || 44 || 1994–present |- | rowspan=3| [[Metropolitano]]|| [[San Martín Line|San Martín]]|| 1,676 ||55|| 1994-2007 |- | [[Roca Line|Roca]] || 1,676 ||252|| 1995-2007 |- | [[Belgrano Sur Line|Belgrano Sur]]|| 1,000 ||58|| 1994-2007 |- | [[Ferrovías]] || [[Belgrano Norte Line|Belgrano Norte]] || 1,000 ||52|| 1994–present |- | rowspan=2| [[Trenes de Buenos Aires]] || [[Mitre Line|Mitre]] || 1,676 ||182|| 1995-2012 |- | [[Sarmiento Line|Sarmiento]] || 1,676 ||167|| 1995-2012 |- | [[Tren de la Costa]] <sup>1</sup> || [[General Bartolomé Mitre Railway|Mitre]] || 1,435 || 15,5 || 1995-2013 |- | rowspan=2 | [[Corredores Ferroviarios]] || [[Mitre Line|Mitre]] || 1,676 ||182|| 2014-15 |- | [[San Martín Line|San Martín]]|| 1,676 ||55|| 2014-15 |- | rowspan=2 | [[Argentren]] || [[Roca Line|Roca]] || 1,676 ||252|| 2014-15 |- | [[Belgrano Sur Line|Belgrano Sur]]|| 1,000 ||58|| 2014-15 |}
'''Notes:''' * <sup>1</sup> ''Took over by [[Trenes Argentinos Operadora Ferroviaria]] when contracts of concession were revoked or expired.''
The concessions were mainly for 10 years, with an optional 10-year extension, except for the Metro and the Línea Urquiza which were for an initial term of 20 years. As in the case of the freight concessions, the government maintained ownership of the assets, whilst the concessionaires undertook to operate their services as described in their original bid. Maximum fares were set by the government but were subject to automatic increases according to service quality and the prevailing rate of inflation. Financial penalties would be levied if agreed levels of service were not achieved.
In spite of these companies receiving large government subsidies,<ref>[http://www.pagina12.com.ar/diario/elpais/subnotas/85053-27304-2007-05-16.html "Los que viven del subsidio", Página/12, 16/05/2007]</ref> the services operated by Metropolitano deteriorated to a point where the concession for the operation of Línea San Martín was revoked in 2004 and concessions for the operation of the other two lines by the company were revoked in 2007.<ref>[http://www.lanacion.com.ar/archivo/nota.asp?nota_id=909332 "Hubo numerosos alertas que no se atendieron"], ''La Nación'', 17 May 2007</ref><ref>[http://www.terra.com.ar/canales/informaciongeneral/160/160328.html "Metropolitano, una compañía con reiteradas sanciones", Terra, 16 May 2007]</ref><ref>[http://www.clarin.com/diario/2007/01/16/laciudad/h-03601.htm "Protestaron contra el ex Roca en Constitución"], ''Clarín'', 16 Jan 2007</ref><ref>[http://www.pagina12.com.ar/diario/elpais/subnotas/1-27309-2007-05-17.html "Lo que pasó se veía venir"], ''Página/12'', 17 May 2007</ref> All three lines were subsecquently operated by transitional [[private company|private consortium]] [[Unidad de Gestión Operativa Ferroviaria de Emergencia|UGOFE]].<ref>[http://www.laprensa.com.ar/391823-La-UGOFE-se-hara-cargo-de-los-servicios-de-las-dos-lineas-ferroviarias.note.aspx "La UGOFE se hará cargo de los servicios de las dos líneas ferroviarias"], ''La Prensa''</ref>
[[Trenes de Buenos Aires]] operated the [[Mitre Line|Mitre]] and [[Sarmiento Line|Sarmiento]] lines until concession was revoked after the [[2012 Buenos Aires rail disaster|Once rail disaster]] on February 22, 2012, at [[Once Station]], [[Buenos Aires]], in which 51 people died and at least 703 people were injured,<ref>{{cite news|title=Argentina train crash in Buenos Aires kills dozens|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-17129858|work=BBC News|accessdate=2012-02-22}}</ref> TBA was placed under [[federal intervention]] on February 28; its concessions to operate the Mitre and Sarmiento lines were ultimately revoked on May 24.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clarin.com/politica/Finalmente-Gobierno-concesion-Sarmiento-TBA_0_706129566.html|title=Finalmente, el Gobierno le sacó las concesiones del Sarmiento y del Mitre a TBA|work=Clarín}}</ref> After the cancellation of the contact, both lines were taken over by transitional consortium [[Unidad de Gestión Operativa Mitre Sarmiento]] (UGOMS).
When [[UGOFE]] and [[UGOMS]] were dissolved, Corredores Ferroviarios (a company part of Grupo Roggio, which also owns [[Metrovías]], a company that operates the [[Buenos Aires Subte]] and Urquiza line since 1994) and Argentren took over the Mitre / San Martín and Belgrano Sur / Roca lines, respectively.<ref>[http://www.clarin.com/politica/Roggio-Emepa-repartiran-manejo-ferrocarriles_0_1030697016.html Roggio y EMEPA se repartirán el manejo de cuatro ferrocarriles] clarin.com</ref><ref>[http://www.pagina12.com.ar/diario/economia/2-260643-2014-11-26.html Trenes cero kilómetro después de cincuenta años/ Cambios Recientes] pagina12.com.ar</ref><ref>[http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1663435-el-gobierno-vuelve-a-privatizar-la-operacion-de-los-trenes-mitre-san-martin-belgrano-sur-y-r "Trenes: le dan a Roggio el Mitre y el San Martín y a Emepa, el Roca y el Belgrano Sur", ''La Nación'', 12 Feb 2014]</ref><ref>[http://www.clarin.com/politica/privadas-volveran-operar-mayoria-ferroviarias_0_1083491853.html "Las privadas volverán a operar la mayoría de las líneas ferroviarias", ''Clarín, 12 Feb 2014]</ref><ref>[http://www.telam.com.ar/notas/201402/51395-el-gobierno-establecio-un-nuevo-regimen-de-operaciones-de-las-lineas-ferroviarias.html "El Gobierno estableció un nuevo régimen de operaciones de las líneas ferroviarias", Telam, 12 Feb 2014]</ref><ref>[http://www.pagina12.com.ar/diario/economia/2-239655-2014-02-12.html "De a uno por línea, para mejor control", ''Página 12'', 12 Feb 2014]</ref><ref>[http://www.enelsubte.com/noticias/metrovias-operara-las-lineas-mitre-y-san-martin-3053 "Metrovías operará las líneas Mitre y San Martín", ''En el Subte'', 12 Feb 2014]</ref> The company operated both lines until the government rescinded the agreement with the company in March 2015.<ref name=ley>[http://www.ieco.clarin.com/economia/Nueva-ley-trenes-esta-lista_0_1315068533.html "Ya está lista la ley que prevé más control estatal sobre los trenes"], ''Clarín'', 5 Mar 2015</ref><ref name="ambito.com">[http://www.ambito.com/noticia.asp?id=780856 "Estado rescindió contrato de trenes a privados y avisó que no pagará indemnizaciones"], ''Ambito Financiero'', 2 Mar 2015</ref><ref name="railwaygazette.com">[http://www.railwaygazette.com/news/single-view/view/buenos-aires-commuter-routes-renationalised.html "Buenos Aires commuter routes renationalised"], ''Railway Gazette'', 3 Mar 2015</ref><ref name="boletinoficial.gov.ar">[http://www.boletinoficial.gov.ar/Avisos/VerPDF.castle?f=20150302&s=01&pd=9&ph=0&sup=False Resolution N° 171/2015 - Official Bulletin of Argentina]</ref>
Apart from Corredores Ferroviarios, other private company, [[Argentren]] S.A., was granted concession to operate the [[Roca Line (Buenos Aires)|Roca]] and [[Belgrano Sur Line (Buenos Aires)|Belgrano Sur]] lines.<ref name="ambito.com"/><ref name="railwaygazette.com"/><ref name="boletinoficial.gov.ar"/> The contract was also revoked by the government in March 2015.<ref name=ley/>
=== Other rail services === On 20 May 1992 the government announced that all [[inter-city rail|inter-city]] passenger services, other than Buenos Aires to [[Mar del Plata]], would be discontinued on January 1, 1993, unless provincial authorities either agreed to assume responsibility for them or selected a private concessionaire to operate them on their behalf.
Provincial governments that took over the services to avoid closures were: * [[Buenos Aires Province|Buenos Aires]], establishing state-owned company [[Ferrobaires]] (1993 to present days) * [[Chaco Province]] operated trains through state-owned [[Servicios Ferroviarios del Chaco]] (1999-2010) * [[Tucumán Province|Tucumán]] also operated a railway service to [[Buenos Aires]] to keep the line active. Services started in 1992 but ceased in 1997. * [[Río Negro Province|Río Negro]] created its own company, named "[[Servicios Ferroviarios Patagónico|Tren Patagónico]]" to operate trains from [[Viedma]] to [[San Carlos de Bariloche|Bariloche]]<ref>[http://www.minutouno.com/notas/319649-avanza-la-reactivacion-del-tren-patagonico "Avanza la reactivación del Tren Patagónico"], Minuto Uno, 16 Apr 2014</ref> that had been under concession since 1993.
On the other hand, ''[[La Trochita]]'' was never privatised and closed in 1992 due to the lack of interest of private investors. Nevertheless, the line would be later reopened, being currently operated by Governments of [[Río Negro Province|Río Negro]] and [[Chubut Province|Chubut]] provinces together.
Long-distance and tourist services granted to private companies are listed below:
{| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:left" | colspan="5" style= "background: #cccccc; color: #00000" | <center> '''Other passenger services privatisation'''</center> |- ! width=250px| Concessionaire ! width=170px| Division ! width=60px| Gauge (mm) ! width=60px| Length (km) ! width=100px| Period |- | [[Tucumán Ferrocarriles]] || rowspan=2| [[Retiro railway station|Retiro]]–[[San Miguel de Tucumán|Tucumán]] || rowspan=2| 1,676 || rowspan=2| 1,260 || 1997-2000 |- | [[Ferrocentral]] <sup>1</sup> || 2004-2014 |- | [[Ferrocarriles Mediterráneos]] || [[Córdoba, Argentina|Córdoba]]–[[Villa María]] || 1,676 || 150 || 1992-2004 |- | [[Ferrocentral]] || [[Tren de las Sierras]] <sup>1</sup> || 1,000 || 150 || 2007-13 |- | [[Servicios Ferroviarios Patagónico]] || [[Viedma]]–[[San Carlos de Bariloche|Bariloche]] || 1,676 || 826 || 1993-? |- | [[Trenes Especiales Argentinos]] || [[Federico Lacroze railway station|F. Lacroze]]–[[Posadas, Misiones|Posadas]] || 1,676 || 1,060 || 2003-2011 |- | ''(unknown)'' || [[Southern Fuegian Railway|Southern Fueguian]] <sup>2</sup> || 0,500 || 7 || 1994–present |- | ''(unknown)'' || rowspan=2| [[Tren a las Nubes]] <sup>3</sup> || rowspan=2| 1,000 || rowspan=2| 217 || 1991-2005 |- | EcoTren || 2005-2014 |}
'''Notes:''' * <sup>1</sup> ''Taken over by [[Trenes Argentinos Operadora Ferroviaria]] when contracts of concession were revoked or expired.'' * <sup>2</sup> ''The Southern Fueguian was not included into any railway division after 1948 [[railway Nationalisation in Argentina|nationalisation]]. It remained closed from 1952 until 1994 when the SF was granted in concession to a private company that completely rebuilt the line.'' * <sup>3</sup> ''Taken over by the Government of Salta after the last concession was revoked.''<ref>[http://www.infobae.com/2014/07/23/1582620-tras-las-fallas-seguridad-salta-estatizo-el-tren-las-nubes "Tras las fallas de seguridad, Salta estatizó el Tren a las Nubes"], ''Infobae'' 23 Jul 2014</ref>

{{infobox person | name = Ron Brunton |birth_name= Ronald Brunton |birth_date = {{birth year and age|1945}}<ref name=theage>[http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2003/05/09/1052280439734.html Ewin Hannan, (10 May 2003), Aunty gets more of the right stuff, ''The Age'']. Retrieved 5 October 2017</ref> |occupation = anthropologist and author |alma_mater = [[La Trobe University]]<ref name=kava/> }} Dr '''Ron Brunton''' is an [[Australia]]n [[Anthropology|anthropologist]]. He is the Director of Encompass Research Pty Ltd and was a Director of the Board of the [[Public broadcasting|public broadcaster]], the [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] for a five-year term from 1 May 2003.
==Biography== Prior to his appointment to the ABC Board, Brunton was a fortnightly columnist for ''[[The Courier-Mail]]'' from 1997–2003; a Senior Fellow at the [[Institute of Public Affairs]], a [[right wing]] [[think tank]] from 1995–2001, and a contributor to the [[Conservatism|conservative]] literary and political journal ''[[Quadrant (magazine)|Quadrant]]''.
In his articles, Brunton was highly critical of the ''[[Bringing Them Home]]'' report on the stolen generations.<ref>[[Hal Wootten|Wootten, Hal]] (1998) [http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/journals/ILB/1998/44.html 'Ron Brunton and Bringing Them Home', the Report of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission into the removal of Aboriginal children from ... ]''[[Indigenous Law Bulletin]]'' 44; 4(12): 12-12]</ref> He has also written scathing criticisms of both the [[Australian High Court|High Court]]'s 1992 ''[[Mabo v Queensland (No 2)|Mabo v Queensland]]'' decision and the [[Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody]]. In addition, he enunciated the view that the "secret women's business" of the [[Ngarrindjeri]] women during the [[Hindmarsh Island bridge controversy]] was a fabrication, and came to the defence of the murdered [[Netherlands|Dutch]] politician [[Pim Fortuyn]] who called on [[Muslim]] immigrants to [[Cultural assimilation|assimilate]] into Dutch society and culture. Prior to his appointment to the Board he was a harsh critic of the ABC itself, accusing it of being part of the "left establishment" and of being a "sucker" for "brainless comment".
Brunton's appointment to the ABC Board by the [[Australian Government]] of [[John Howard]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Anthropologist gets nod for ABC board|publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]|work=ABC News|date=2 May 2003|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2003/05/02/845928.htm|accessdate=11 May 2008|location=Australia }}</ref> created controversy with left-wing ABC supporters given his conservative views.<ref>{{cite press release|title=The usual suspects - Dr Ron Brunton appointed to the ABC Board|publisher=Friends of the ABC|date=2 May 2003|url=http://friendsoftheabc.org/suspects.htm|accessdate=3 December 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060614204640/http://friendsoftheabc.org/suspects.htm <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate=14 June 2006}}</ref>
Encompass Research Pty Ltd is an organisation engaged in anthropological and [[socio-economic]] [[research]], concentrating on [[native title]], [[Australian Aboriginal culture|indigenous heritage]], [[immigration]] and [[Natural environment|environmental]] issues.
Brunton has published a range of research papers and books on anthropological issues and has lectured in anthropology at universities in Australia and at the [[University of Papua New Guinea]]. He has also stood as an [[expert witness]] in a number of [[native title]] court cases across Australia, having been engaged by parties involved in native title [[litigation]].
===Education=== He completed his Ph.D. at [[La Trobe University]] with a thesis on [[kava]] use in [[Melanesia]].<ref name=kava>{{Citation | author1=Brunton, Ron (Ronald) | title=The abandoned narcotic : kava and cultural instability in Melanesia | publication-date=1989 | publisher=Cambridge University Press | isbn=978-0-521-37375-3 }}</ref> He had in 1973 completed a M.A. with a thesis titled ''Social stratification, trade and ceremonial exchange in Melanesia'' at the [[University of Sydney]].<ref>{{Citation | author1=Brunton, Ron (Ronald) | title=Social stratification, trade and ceremonial exchange in Melanesia | publication-date=1973 | publisher=[s.n.] | url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/22023886 | accessdate=5 October 2017 }}</ref>
