{{Infobox person | name = Ryōichi Sasakawa
笹川 良一 | image = RyoichiSasakawa face.jpg{{!}}border | caption = | parents = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1899|5|4}} | birth_place = [[Osaka]], [[Empire of Japan|Japan]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1995|7|18|1899|6|4}} | death_place = [[Tokyo]], Japan | death_cause = [[Stroke]] | occupation = [[Business]]man, [[Sports administrator]] | years_active = | spouse = | children = | relatives = }} {{nihongo|'''Ryōichi Sasakawa'''|笹川 良一|Sasakawa Ryōichi|May 4, 1899 – July 18, 1995}} was a [[Japanese people|Japanese]] businessman, politician, and philanthropist. He was born in [[Minoh, Osaka]]. In the 1930s and during the [[Second World War]] he was active both in finance and in politics, actively supporting the Japanese war effort including raising his own paramilitary units. He was elected to the [[Japanese parliament]] during the war. After Japan's defeat he was imprisoned for a time as a suspected war criminal, and then found financial success in various business ventures including [[Kyōtei|motorboat racing]] and ship building. He supported anticommunist activities, including the [[World League for Freedom and Democracy|World Anti-Communist League]]. In 1951 he helped found the [[Nippon Foundation]] and became its first president. The foundation has done charitable work around the world, for which it and Sasakawa have received many official honors. == Prewar activity == In the 1930s, during the [[Second Sino-Japanese War|Sino-Japanese War]], Sasakawa rose to prominence by using wealth gained in rice speculation{{harvp|Sato|2006|p=12}} to build a voluntary flying squad within Japan for the purpose of providing trained pilots in case of a national emergency.{{harvp|Sato|2006|p=25}} He also built an air defense field, donating it to the army. Once Japan began to coordinate its air power in 1941, Sasakawa dissolved his voluntary flying group and gave all of its facilities and aircraft to the nation.{{harvp|Sato|2006|pp=27–28}} In addition, he used the various mining interests that he had accumulated to support the army in a more concrete fashion.{{harvp|Sato|2006|p=13}} Sasaka was more interested in supporting the war effort than making a profit, with one biographer noting that "his family records show ... that his mining ventures were not as profitable in wartime as they could have been".{{harvp|Sato|2006|p=15}} [[File:A Japanese Tragedy 1946 film (12) wmplayer 2013-04-09 19-27-49-090 R.jpg|thumb|Yoshio Kodama]] In addition, the 1930s saw Sasakawa take the helm of the Kokusui Taishu-to, or Patriotic People's Party (PPP).{{harvp|Sato|2006|p=16}} This small organization was one of the many right-wing groups that sprang up in Japan in the lead-up to World War II.{{harvp|Sato|2006|pp=16–17}} It was in this connection that he first met [[Yoshio Kodama]], who was at that time a member.{{harvp|Sato|2006|p=23}} In 1935, Sasakawa and twelve other leading members of the PPP were arrested and held for three years on suspicion of having ordered the blackmail of several leading companies, such as Takashimaya, the Hankyu Railway, and Tokyo Life Insurance.{{harvp|Sato|2006|p=42}} Though he was eventually acquitted, the jail time and the subsequent appeals process took a total of 6 years, leading up the opening year of World War II.{{harvp|Sato|2006|p=43}} In the end, the prosecution itself revealed that the charges against him had been based more on perception of the PPP as "dangerous", than on actual evidence of blackmail.{{harvp|Sato|2006|p=45}} Sasakawa's trials ended in August 1941.{{harvp|Sato|2006|p=232}} In December that year, World War II broke out [[Pacific War|in the Pacific]], and in April 1942, Sasakawa won a seat in the Japanese Diet, taking one of only 85 out of 466 seats that were captured by non-government-backed candidates.{{harvp|Sato|2006|p=50}} The reason that such candidates were so few was that it was wartime, and those in power were doing all they could to control policy while maintaining a mask of parliamentary democracy.{{harvp|Sato|2006|pp=50–52}} Sasakawa joined the Diet nearly a half year after the war began, as a member of the "opposition". In the Diet, he stood against the government's suppression of the freedom of speech and its pressure for the conformity of all parliamentarians.{{harvp|Sato|2006|pp=52–53}} However, his efforts in this vein were largely unsuccessful, and he spent much of the war outside of the Diet, touring Manchuria and China, visiting prisons around the country, and cheering those on the home front.{{harvp|Sato|2006|p=54}} He advocated war extension. During the war he flew a squadron bomber to Rome and met Mussolini.Frédéric, Louis; Encyclopaedia of Asian Civilisations; Paris 1984, Vol. VIII, p. 36 == Sugamo prison == [[File:Sugamo Prison2.JPG|thumb|Sugamo prison]] At the end of the war, Sasakawa entered the occupation-run Sugamo prison. While until a short time before his arrest, there was little possibility of his detainment, much less as a Class A war crimes suspect,{{harvp|Sato|2006|p=78}} from October to November, 1945, he launched a campaign of twenty or so speeches in Osaka, decrying victor's justice and demanding to be taken as a prisoner so that he could help defend Japan in the Tokyo war crimes trials.{{harvp|Sato|2006|p=76–78}} He was "motivated by a desire to speak out in defense of the emperor and in the interests of Japan at the Tokyo Trials". The US summary for his arrest, dated December 4, 1945 reads as follows: {{quote|Sasakawa should be arrested for the following reasons: first, for leading campaigns instigating aggression, nationalism and hostility against the United States. And second, for his continued vigorous activities in an organization that strongly impedes the development of democracy in Japan.Awaya Kentaro and Yoshida Yutaka, eds., Vol. 24, Kokusai Kensatsukyoku (IPS) Jinmon Chosho [Official records of interrogations by examining prosecutors] (Tokyo: Nihon Tosho Center, 1993, 126., quoting Civil Intelligence Section (CIS) records, Minkan Joho Koku, December 4, 1945.)}} While in prison, Sasakawa was able to establish connections with many of the men who had led Japan during the war, and who would go on to reassume these roles after their release. He also came into further contact with [[Yoshio Kodama]], though the exact nature of their prison relationship does not seem to have been as positive as it had been when they were both members of the PPP. (In prison, Kodama pursued a policy of collaborating with his captors, naming names and making questionable statements that put other prisoners at a disadvantage. As part of this policy, he asked that his testimony about Sasakawa be kept secret, and it would appear that Sasakawa never found out about it.{{harvp|Sato|2006|pp=97–103}}) == Postwar activity == On December 23, 1948, [[Hideki Tōjō]] and six other Class A war criminals were hanged. The next day, all Class A suspects who had not been indicted were released (aside from the seven who were executed, eighteen were given very long or life sentences.) Sasakawa and Kodama were among those who were released. There is much speculation surrounding Sasakawa's release. While some suggest that there was simply not enough evidence to indict him of Class A war crimes,{{harvp|Sato|2006|p=87}} others believe it was due to a lack of resources available to carry out trials of all suspected war criminals.{{Citation | last=Postel-Vinay | first=Karoline | publication-date= | title=History on Trial: French Nippon Foundation Sues Scholar for Libel to Protect the Honor of Sasakawa Ryōichi | periodical=The Asia-Pacific Journal: Japan Focus | volume= | issue= | pages= | url=http://japanfocus.org/-Karoline-Postel_Vinay/3349 | accessdate=2012-04-20 }} The two men subsequently chose different paths in life, but maintained their friendship until the death of Kodama in 1984.{{harvp|Sato|2006|p=24}} Sasakawa became deeply involved in the [[occupied Japan|post-war reconstruction]]; though he never again entered politics, he used his considerable influence to bolster business and political parties. The most effective of his post-war activities was the creation of a gambling industry that is still in existence today. Along with his friends [[Syngman Rhee]], the Korean dictator, and [[Chiang Kai-shek]], the Chinese nationalist leader, he founded the [[World League for Freedom and Democracy|World Anti-Communist League]]. Among other coups, the league claims to have played a part in the 1966 overthrow of Indonesia's President [[Sukarno]]. Sasakawa stated once: "I am the world's richest fascist."[http://www.globalresearch.ca/drugs-guns-and-nukes-iran-as-the-new-dope-incorporated/29839 Drugs, Guns and Nukes: Iran as the New 'Dope, Incorporated'] - Global Research, 18 March 2012{{Citation | publication-date= | date=August 26, 1974 | title=The Godfather-san | periodical=[[Time (magazine)|TIME]] | volume= | issue= | pages= | url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,944948,00.html | accessdate=2007-10-22 }}[http://www.benhills.com/articles/japan-unlimited/item/64-sasakawa-the-philanthropist-with-the-heart-of-a-fascist Sasakawa: The philanthropist with the heart of a fascist] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120318031652/http://www.benhills.com/articles/japan-unlimited/item/64-sasakawa-the-philanthropist-with-the-heart-of-a-fascist |date=2012-03-18 }} (24.10.2011) Sasakawa supported [[Unification Church]] founder [[Sun Myung Moon]] in his anti-communist activities.{{cite web |url=http://www.mediachannel.org/originals/moontranscript2.shtml |title=The Resurrection of Reverend Moon |date=21 January 1992 |work=Frontline |publisher=PBS | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110107084418/http://www.mediachannel.org/originals/moontranscript2.shtml|archivedate=7 January 2011}}[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E0CEEDB1F3FF932A15752C0A964958260 Sun Myung Moon Changes Robes], ''[[New York Times]]'', January 21, 1992 Ryōichi Sasakawa helped form the [[World Karate Federation|World Union of Karate-do Organizations]] in 1970, also serving as its president.{{cite book | editor1-first = Ramin | editor1-last = Kordi | editor2-first = Nicola | editor2-last = Maffulli | editor3-first = Randall R. | editor3-last = Wroble | editor4-first = W. Angus |display-editors = 3 | editor4-last = Wallace | last = Arriaza | first = Rafael | title = Combat Sports Medicine | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Zwok7ECHn0wC&pg=PA288&lpg=PA288&dq=jacques+delcourt+1966+european+karate&source=bl&ots=LRf_kja9hL&sig=-Di9AAt9bJCsfXDEbvcZyX4TcK4&hl=en&sa=X&ei=cyVeVImmMuPe7AaBq4D4CA&ved=0CDYQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=jacques%20delcourt%201966%20european%20karate&f=false | publisher = | volume = | issue = | pages = 288 | chapter = Chapter 16: Karate | doi = | accessdate = 8 November 2014 }} Sasakawa died July 18, 1995. He had three sons: Masatada, Takashi and [[Yohei Sasakawa|Yohei]].{{cite journal | title=In the Name of the Godfather |author1=Marshall, Andrew |author2=Toyama, Michiko | journal=[[Tokyo Journal]] |date=October 1994 | pages=29–35}} == Nippon Foundation == [[File:Ryoichi Sasakawa bust at WHO building Geneva.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Bust of Sasakawa at the WHO in [[Geneva]]]] In 1951 – after extensive bribery of parliamenticians on his behalf – the [[Japanese Diet]] passed the Motorboat Racing Law – an invention of Sasakawa's. Under this law, [[Kyōtei|motorboat races]] are held at 24 locations around the nation for the purpose of both bolstering the local economies and providing the revenue needed to support 1) the reconstruction of Japan's maritime industry, and 2) welfare projects around the country. In later years, international projects were also added. The law established that the distribution of the monies to support projects was to be performed by the Japan Shipbuilding Industry Foundation, a body that eventually came to be known as the [[Nippon Foundation]].{{cite web | url=http://www.nippon-foundation.or.jp/en/who/about/history/01.html | title=Foundation History | publisher=The Nippon Foundation | accessdate=February 6, 2016}} Sasakawa became the foundation's chairman. Public and governmental focus on the issue drove Sasakawa to take pains to make the system as clear as possible.{{harvp|Sato|2006|p=187}} [[Kyōtei]], a form of boat racing, is one of the sports for which [[Gambling in Japan|gambling]] is officially allowed in Japan, established as a means to help with restoring the nation's shipbuilding industry.{{Citation|title=The Nippon Foundation's Resources |url=http://www.nippon-foundation.or.jp/eng/who/resources.html |accessdate=December 5, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090103101106/http://www.nippon-foundation.or.jp/eng/who/resources.html |archivedate=January 3, 2009 }} It was largely responsible for Japan's meteoric rise to become one of the world's maritime leaders by the 1960s.{{harvp|Sato|2006|pp=175–176}} The system is regulated by the department of transport, and many of the foundations Sasakawa later created through grants by The Nippon Foundation were led by previous employees of the department of transport. The system of farming out former government employees to businesses and foundations has long been common, legal practice in Japan, though one that Sasakawa himself viewed with suspicion.{{harvp|Sato|2006|p=186}} Under Sasakawa's leadership, The Nippon Foundation made charitable contributions both in Japan and around the world, working with the United Nations on maritime law[https://www.un.org/depts/los/nippon/ The Nippon Foundation of Japan Fellowship Programme: Human Resources Development and Advancement of the Legal Order of the World's Oceans] - United Nations, retrieved 28 March 2013 and with the World Health Organization, donating over $70m to fight leprosy.[http://www.who.int/lep/partners/tnf/en/ Partners: The Nippon Foundation] - World Health Organization, retrieved 28 March 2013 The group also founded or funded a number of other organizations, such as the United States-Japan Foundation;{{Citation | title=The United States-Japan Foundation's Website | url= http://www.us-jf.org/ | accessdate=December 5, 2008}} The Sasakawa Peace Foundation;{{Citation | title=The Sasakawa Peace Foundation's Website | url=http://www.spf.org/e/index.html | accessdate=December 5, 2008}} the [[Sasakawa Africa Association]], an expansion of [[Norman Borlaug]]'s [[Green Revolution]] to [[Africa]];[http://www.csmonitor.com/1990/1016/ptan.html Program Plants Seed of Change], ''[[Christian Science Monitor]]'', October 16, 1990[http://www.csmonitor.com/1994/0629/29091.html Borlaug: sowing 'Green Revolution' among African leaders], ''[[Christian Science Monitor]]'', June 29, 1994{{cite web | url=http://www.saa-safe.org/wwa/history.html | title=SAA HISTORY IN BRIEF | publisher=Sasakawa Africa Association | accessdate=June 13, 2014}} and the [[University of Houston]]'s [[Sasakawa International Center for Space Architecture]] (SICSA).{{cite web | url=http://www.uh.edu/sicsa/welcome/background/index.php | title=SICSA Background and Overview | publisher=[[University of Houston]] | accessdate=June 13, 2014 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150413180019/http://www.uh.edu/sicsa/welcome/background/index.php | archivedate=April 13, 2015 | df= }} == Honours == * 1976 : Order of Diplomatic Service Merit, 1st class (South Korea) * 1977 : Order of Brilliant Star, Grand Cordon (Republic of China) * 1978 : [[Order of the Sacred Treasure]], 1st class, Grand Cordon (Japan) * 1980 : Order of the Golden Heart (Philippines) * 1987 : [[Order of the Rising Sun]], 1st Class, Grand Cordon (Japan) * 1989 : [[Order of the White Elephant]], Knight Grand Cross (Thailand) * 1993 : [[Ordre des Arts et des Lettres]], Commandeur (France) == See also == * [[Gandhi Memorial International Foundation]] * [[Russian cruiser Admiral Nakhimov (1885)]] ==References== ===Footnotes=== {{Reflist|30em}} ===Works cited=== {{refbegin}} *{{Citation |last=Boneau |first=Denis |publication-date=May 2004 |title=Sasakawa, a Respected War Criminal |periodical=VoltaireNet |url= http://www.voltairenet.org/article30028.html}} *{{Citation |last=Goodman |first=Walter |publication-date=January 21, 1992 |title=Review/Television; Sun Myung Moon Changes Robes |periodical=New York Times |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E0CEEDB1F3FF932A15752C0A964958260&sec=&spon=}} *{{Citation |last=Kaplan |first=David and Dubro, Alec |publication-date=2003 |date=2003-02-01 |title=Yakuza: Japan's Criminal Underworld |pages=esp. 64–65 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=W1vi31vifg0C&pg=PA65&vq=sun+myung+moon+sasakawa&dq=Yakuza+by+David+E.+Kaplan+and+Alec+Dubro |isbn=978-0-520-21562-7}} *{{Citation |last=Koehler |first=Robert |publication-date=January 21, 1992 |title='Frontline' Penetratingly Investigates Rev. Moon |periodical=Los Angeles Times |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/2104060.html?dids=2104060&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS&type=current&date=Jan+21%2C+1992&author=Koehler%2C+Robert&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&edition=&startpage=F9&desc=%27Frontline%27+Penetratingly+Investigates+Rev.+Moon}} *{{Citation |last=Samuels |first=Richard J.|author-link=Richard J. Samuels|publication-date=December 2001 |title=Kishi and Corruption: An Anatomy of the 1955 System |periodical=University of San Francisco Japan Policy Research Institute |issue=Working Paper No. 83 |url=http://www.jpri.org/publications/workingpapers/wp83.html}} *{{Citation |last=Samuels |first=Richard J. |publication-date=2003 |year=2003 |title=Machiavelli's Children |periodical=Published by Cornell University Press |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RNv1YCA3IDkC&printsec=frontcover#PPA245,M1 |isbn=978-0-8014-3492-1}} *{{Citation |last=Sato |first=Seizaburo |publication-date=2006 |title=Sasakawa Ryoichi: A Life |ref=harv}} {{refend}} == External links == * [http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/z?r102:S08SE2-64: U.S. Senate "Tribute to the Honorable Ryoichi Sasakawa"] * [http://www.jpri.org/publications/workingpapers/wp83.html Kishi and Corruption: An Anatomy of the 1955 System, Japan Policy Research Institute (JPRI), University of San Francisco] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sasakawa, Ryoichi}} [[Category:1899 births]] [[Category:1995 deaths]] [[Category:Japanese activists]] [[Category:Japanese anti-communists]] [[Category:Japanese businesspeople]] [[Category:Japanese fascists]] [[Category:Japanese philanthropists]] [[Category:People from Minoh, Osaka]] [[Category:Members of the House of Representatives (Empire of Japan)]] [[Category:Japanese prisoners and detainees]] [[Category:Prisoners and detainees of the United States military]] [[Category:Grand Cordons of the Order of the Rising Sun]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of the Sacred Treasure, 1st class]] [[Category:Commandeurs of the Ordre des Arts et des Lettres]] [[Category:Order of the Golden Heart]] [[Category:Members of the Order of Diplomatic Service Merit]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = Kingdom of Saudi Arabia
Saudi Arabian General Investment Authority (SAGIA) |nativename = '''الهيئة العامة للإستثمار''' |nativename_a = |nativename_r = |logo = [[Image:SAGIA Logo.png|frameless]] |logo_width = 150px |logo_caption = |jurisdiction = [[Saudi Arabia]] |headquarters = [[Riyadh]] |coordinates = {{Coord|24|38|57|N|46|44|8|E|display=title}} |chief1_name = Ibrahim Al-Omar |chief1_position = Governor |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |chief3_name = |chief3_position = |parent_agency = |child1_agency = |child2_agency = |website = {{URL|www.sagia.gov.sa}} |seal=|formed=|employees=|budget=|chief4_name=|chief4_position=|chief5_name=|chief5_position=|chief6_name=|chief6_position=|chief7_name=|chief7_position=|chief8_name=|chief8_position=|chief9_name=|chief9_position=|parent_department=}} The '''Saudi Arabian General Investment Authority''' (SAGIA) is the foreign investment license provider for the Kingdom.{{cite web| url=https://www.ft.com/content/3c6413ce-a381-11e3-aa85-00144feab7de |title=Saudi red tape frustrates foreign investment| first=Abeer| last= Allam| date=30 March 2014| publisher=Financial Times| access-date=3 December 2016}} It was created by the [[Saudi Arabia|Saudi Government]] on 10 April 2000, as part of measures geared towards formalizing the process of [[economic liberalization]]. The government body awards investment licensing online and reports to the president of the [[Supreme Economic Council of Saudi Arabia|Supreme Economic Council]]. SAGIA’s headquarters are located in [[Riyadh]], with three other business centers located in Saudi Arabia: [[Medina]], [[Dammam]] and [[Jeddah]]. In order to facilitate investment, a larger network of business centers has been announced.{{cite web| url=http://www.aimcongress.com/en/sponsors-2015/invest-saudi/ |title=Invest Saudi| publisher= UAE Ministry of Economy| access-date=3 December 2016}} ==History== Prior to 2000, Saudi Arabia had failed to attract significant foreign investments in its telecommunications, transportation, and power industries despite being the largest market in the Gulf. Foreign investors were deterred by several factors including incomplete economic data, restrictive visa policies for workers, and an extremely conservative cultural environment.Khalid Al-Yahya, [https://www.innovations.harvard.edu/sites/default/files/16616.pdf First Arab Regional Forum on Innovations in Governance], ''Harvard.edu'', November 2006 Since 2016, the SAGIA holds a central position in the deployment of Saudi Arabia's [[Saudi Vision 2030|Vision 2030]].[https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/SAGIA.pdf Saudi Arabia Beyond Oil], ''Wko.at'', 13 December 2016 ===Creation=== Intending to liberalize the nation's trade and investment programs, diversify the economy, and join the [[World Trade Organization]], the Saudi Arabian Council of Ministers initiated the Saudi Arabian General Investment Authority (SAGIA) in April 2000. Under the Council of Ministers Resolution No. 2 dated April 9, 2000, the Authority was created as a vehicle for investment in Saudi Arabia, with the purpose of sustaining economic growth and addressing investment affairs nationwide, including foreign investment.[https://www.sagia.gov.sa/en/InvestmentIncentivesandRegulations/LawsAndRegulations/SubCategory_Library/Implementing%20Regulations%20of%20the%20Foreign%20Investment%20Act.pdf The Saudi Arabian General Investment Authority Board Resolution No. (2/74)], ''Sagia.gov.sa'' ===10 x 10 program=== The objective of SAGIA’s “10 x 10” program, which ran from 2005 to 2010, was to place [[Saudi Arabia]] among the world’s top ten competitive investment destinations by 2010. SAGIA created the National Competitiveness Center (NCC) to compare the performance of Saudi Arabia’s investment opportunities to more than 300 indicators of global competitiveness, assessed in such publications as the [[World Bank]]’s ''Doing Business'' report, the [[World Economic Forum]]’s ''[[Global Competitiveness Report]]'', and the [[International Institute for Management Development|IMD]]’s ''World Competitiveness Yearbook''.[http://www.sagia.gov.sa/english/index.php?page=ncc/ NCC (National Competitveness Center)Overview ] According to the World Bank ''Doing Business'' report, Saudi Arabia rose from number 67 in 2005 to number 16 in 2009.Oxford Business Group, [https://books.google.com/books?id=gMPjxHzG1xQC&lpg=PA24&ots=oDR3afIOrT&dq=sagia%2010x10%20program&hl=en&pg=PA24#v=onepage&q=sagia%2010x10%20program&f=false On top of the world], ''The Report: Saudi Arabia'' on ''Books.google.com'', 2008 ===Economic Cities program=== Launched in 2006, the Economic Cities program was designed to drive toward greater competitiveness, [[job creation]], and economic diversification. In developing economic cities, over a thousand of the world’s [[free economic zone|free zones]] were surveyed. The sixty deemed most successful were studied to determine key success factors. The objectives of the Economic Cities were to promote regional development, achieve economic diversification, create jobs, and enhance competitiveness in Saudi Arabia. Four new cities were identified and thus developed: [[King Abdullah Economic City]], [[Jazan Economic City]], [[Prince Abdulaziz Bin Mousaed Economic City]], and the [[Knowledge Economic City, Medina]]. ===Foreign ownership=== In October 2011, [[Pfizer]] signed an agreement with SAGIA to set up its first manufacturing plant in King Abdullah Economic City. In June 2016, SAGIA gave Pfizer 100% foreign ownership of its legal entity in Saudi Arabia.[https://www.sagia.gov.sa/en/PartnerofSuccess/Pages/Pfizer.aspx Success stories: Pfizer], ''Sagia.gov.sa'' In August 2017, SAGIA announced allowing 100 percent foreign ownership in the engineering business, after consultations.Frank Kane, [http://www.arabnews.com/node/1141826/saudi-arabia Saudi Arabia to allow 100% foreign ownership of engineering firms], ''Arabnews.com'', 9 August 2017 ==Activities== The SAGIA is responsible for three main functions: making improvements to increase the Kingdom's competitiveness as an investment destination; building upon the quality of service and value proposition offered to investors; and offering new investment opportunities to attract businesses and investors alike, to help advance Saudi Arabia's economic diversification agenda.[https://www.weforum.org/organizations/saudi-arabian-general-investment-authority-sagia Saudi Arabian General Investment Authority (SAGIA)], ''Weforum.com'' Since its creation in 2000, SAGIA also addresses internal obstacles such as [[Women's rights in Saudi Arabia|women's rights]] in the workplace to tackle issues related to the investment climate. SAGIA acts as provider of all investment-related services in the Kingdom: Advisory services, business match-making, liaison and coordination across government departments, instant online licenses. In 2009 the Kingdom was listed as 8th largest in the worldwide ranking of [[Foreign Direct Investment]] (FDI) recipients.Omar G. Aziz, [http://researchdirect.uws.edu.au/islandora/object/uws%3A36430/datastream/PDF/view Foreign Direct Investment in Arab Economies], ''Uws.edu.au'', 2015 The SAGIA organizes the Global Competitiveness Forum is an annual program of activities held in [[Riyadh]], [[Saudi Arabia]].[http://gcf.org.sa/en/TheEvent/About/Pages/default.aspx About GCF] == Governance == The Authority’s board of directors comprises 14 directors from the Saudi private and public sectors. Prince [[Saud Bin Khalid Al-Faisal]] has been deputy governor of SAGIA since December 2010. Governors of SAGIA served four-year terms, as follows: *2000-2004: Abdullah bin Faisal bin Turki Al Saud{{cite web|title=Who's Who: The House of Saud: Prince Abdullah bin Faisal bin Turki Al-Saud|url=https://www.pbs.org/wnet/wideangle/episodes/the-saudi-question/whos-who-the-house-of-saud/prince-abdullah-bin-faisal-bin-turki-al-saud/2885/|work=PBS|accessdate=7 June 2012}} *March 2004-May 2012: Amr Al Dabbagh *May 2012-April 2017: Abdullatif bin Ahmed Al Othman *Since April 2017: Ibrahim bin Abdul Rahman Alomar ==See also== * [[List of company registers]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} == External links == *[http://www.saudincc.org.sa/ The National Competitiveness Center] *[http://www.gcf.org.sa/ The Global Competitiveness Forum] {{Saudi Arabia topics}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Authority, Saudi Arabian General Investment}} [[Category:2000 establishments in Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Business organisations based in Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Government organisations of Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Jeddah]] [[Category:Investment promotion agencies]] [[Category:Finance in Saudi Arabia]]

{{primary sources|date=January 2010}} The '''Schwab Foundation for Social Entrepreneurship''' provides platforms at the country, regional and global levels to promote [[social entrepreneur]]ship. The Foundation is a [[Non-profit|not-for-profit]] organization, founded in 1998. Its purpose is to "advance social entrepreneurship and to foster social entrepreneurs as an important catalyst for societal innovation and progress."<ref name = Schwab-about>Schwab Foundation for Social Entrepreneurship [http://www.schwabfound.org/content/about-us "About us."] Retrieved: 2013-08-06.</ref> The Foundation is under the legal supervision of the [[Federal administration of Switzerland|Swiss Federal Government]]. Its headquarters are in [[Geneva, Switzerland]]. Each year the Foundation selects 20-25 Social Entrepreneurs through a global “ Social Entrepreneur of the Year” competition.
== History == [[file:Hilde Schwab at the WEF Social Entrepreneurs Wrap-up.jpg|thumb|Hilde Schwab at the WEF Social Entrepreneurs Wrap-up in 2018]] In 1998, Klaus and [[Hilde Schwab]] decided to create the independent not-for-profit Schwab Foundation for Social Entrepreneurship in 1998.<ref name="ElkingtonHartigan2008">{{cite book|author1=John Elkington|author2=Pamela Hartigan|title=The Power of Unreasonable People: How Social Entrepreneurs Create Markets That Change the World|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2kWbh9BEicMC|date=5 February 2008|publisher=Harvard Business Press|isbn=978-1-4221-6354-2}}</ref> Its mission was to promote social innovation. It was a complementary foundation to the [[World Economic Forum]] which [[Klaus Schwab]] had founded in 1971.<ref name="ElkingtonHartigan2008"/>
[[Pamela Hartigan]], who joined in October 2000, was its first managing director. The Foundation is financed from the initial endowment provided by Klaus and Hilde Schwab plus grants and fees for services provided to individuals, foundations or companies.
==Activities== The Foundation encourages community building between the activists it identifies. (260 people in 2013). It tries to encourage the spread of ideas and providing backing from corporations and political, academic and communication leaders. The chosen social entrepreneurs are included in the Forum's initiatives and they serve on the Forum’s Global Agenda Councils. {{close paraphrase|section|source=http://www.schwabfound.org/content/about-us-0|date=January 2014}} The Foundation works with selected companies to advance activities of social entrepreneurs and initiatives that support social entrepreneurship. The Foundation identifies rising social entrepreneurs under the age of 40 through its Forum of Young Global Leaders. Scholarship opportunities for executive education opportunities are offered to selected social entrepreneurs in conjunction with Harvard and Stanford Universities and INSEAD. Case studies on specific social entrepreneurs are provided to leading academic institutions to incorporate into undergraduate and graduate level courses.<ref name = Schwab-about/>
== Foundation Board == As of January 2015, the Foundation Board<ref>[http://www.schwabfound.org/content/foundation-board The Schwab Foundation Board]</ref> consisted of: *[[Hilde Schwab]] (Chairperson, Co-Founder) *[[Klaus Schwab]] (Co-Founder) *Rick Aubry (Social Entrepreneur & Educator, [[Tulane University]], [[United States]]) *[[Paulo Coelho]] (Author) *[[David Gergen]] (Director, Center for Public Leadership, [[John F. Kennedy School of Government]], [[Harvard University]], [[United States]]) *[[Princess Mathilde of Belgium]] (Honorary Board Member) *[[Zanele Mbeki]] (Former First Lady of [[South Africa]]) *[[Muhammad Yunus]] (Managing Director of [[Bangladesh]]'s [[Grameen Bank]])
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.schwabfound.org Schwab Foundation website]

{{Chinese Indonesian name|[[Tanoto]]}} {{Infobox person | name = Sukanto Tanoto
{{linktext|陳|江|和}}[http://www.forbeschina.com/list/988 2010福布斯 印度尼西亚40富豪榜] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928121708/http://www.forbeschina.com/list/988 |date=2011-09-28 }} Forbes China, 2010{{cite news| title=From rags to US$2.8b fortune |publisher=Business Times Singapore |author=Laurel Teo |date=2007-04-07 |accessdate=2007-10-15 |url=http://www.rgmi.com/index.php/component/option,com_docman/Itemid,/task,doc_download/gid,8/ |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070705183323/http://www.rgmi.com/index.php/component/option,com_docman/Itemid,/task,doc_download/gid,8/ |archivedate = 2007-07-05}} | other_names = | birth_date = | birth_place = | residence = [[Indonesia]] | citizenship = [[Indonesia]] | occupation = | networth = | spouse = Tinah Bingei Tanoto | children = Andre Tanoto Imelda Tanoto Belinda Tanoto Anderson Tanoto }} {{Infobox Chinese | title= Sukanto Tanoto
([[Chinese Indonesian name]]) | t={{linktext|陳|江|和}} | s={{linktext|陈|江|和}} | p=Chén Jiānghé | showflag=jyp }} '''Sukanto Tanoto''' ({{zh|first=t|s={{linktext|陈|江|和}}|t={{linktext|陳|江|和}}|p=Chén Jiānghé}}; 25 December 1949) is an [[Indonesia]]n businessman involved primarily in the lumber industry. As of 2013 he was considered to be one of Indonesia's wealthiest individuals with a [[net worth]] of [[US$]] 2.3 billion.{{cite web|date=November 2013|title=Indonesia's 50 Richest List| url=https://www.forbes.com/indonesia-billionaires/list/|publisher=Forbes|language=|last=|first=|accessdate=29 April 2014}}{{cite web| publisher=The Jakarta Post | url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2008/03/07/five-indonesians-039forbes039-rich-list.html |date=2008-03-08 |accessdate=2008-03-13 |title=Five Indonesians on 'Forbes' rich list}} After starting as a supplier of equipment and materials for the state-owned oil firm [[Pertamina]], Tanoto moved into the [[forest industry]] in 1973.{{cite web| publisher=[[Forbes]] | url=https://www.forbes.com/lists/2006/80/06indonesia_Sukanto-Tanoto-family_USK7.html |title=Sukanto Tanoto and family |date=2006-08-06 |accessdate=2007-10-15}} Tanoto's business interests are represented by the [[Royal Golden Eagle]] (RGE) group of companies (previously known as Raja Garuda Mas).{{cite web|date=June 24, 2012|title=THE PULP & PAPER KING SHARES HIS STORY| url=http://www.rgei.com/files/media_releases/Fortune%20Indonesia%20Magazine%20article%20-%20English%20translation.pdf|publisher=Fortune Indonesia|language=|last=Ratnasari a|first=Evi|accessdate=28 April 2014}} ==Biography== Born in [[Medan]], [[North Sumatra]] province, on [[Christmas Day]] 1949, Tanoto is the oldest of seven boys. His father was an immigrant from [[Putian]] city in [[China]]'s [[Fujian]] province. In 1966, Tanoto's education was abruptly interrupted after Chinese schools were shut down by then-President [[Suharto]]'s [[New Order (Indonesia)|new regime]]. He was prohibited from attending national schools due to his parents' Chinese citizenship. When his father suffered a stroke, Tanoto was left to run the family business. He gradually moved beyond basic trading to winning contracts in building gas pipelines for multinationals. During the 1972 oil crisis that increased prices dramatically, Tanoto took advantage of clients rapidly expanding their operations. With this injection of capital, Tanoto turned his attention to another business in 1973, noticing that Indonesia exported raw logs for conversion into plywood in countries like Japan or Taiwan, before importing the finished plywood back to Indonesia at great cost. Tanoto recognized an opportunity to develop his own plywood mill in Indonesia. However, he required a permit to do so. Under the Suharto regime, permits were sought from politicians who often served as [[Armed Forces of Indonesia|army]] generals. Tanoto was forced to work with a general who gave his blessing and was quickly convinced of the mill's potential after seeing the completed factory, with Tanoto citing the potential value-add to Indonesia's economy and the creation of new jobs. The plant began operations in 1975 after being inaugurated by Suharto. Slowly, from the plywood business, his company branched out into palm oil as well as pulp and paper.{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/06/14/hard-work-the-key-for-the-family-behind-singapore-based-resources-giant-rge.html|title=CNBC Lasting Legacy: Hard work the key for the family behind Singapore-based resources giant RGE|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=}} Tanoto is a self-educated entrepreneur but regretted his interrupted education. He learned English word-for-word using a Chinese-English dictionary and finally attended business school in Jakarta in the mid-1970s. He also undertook further studies at INSEAD in Fontainebleau, France. In 1997, Tanoto elected to settle in [[Singapore]] with his family, establishing his company's headquarters there. Three of his children are active within RGE and its businesses. His son, [[Anderson Tanoto|Anderson,]] is an RGE director.{{Cite newspaper|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/an-indonesian-scion-grapples-with-his-familys-past-1445903371|title=An Indonesian Scion Grapples with His Family's Past|journal=Wall Street Journal|date=2015-10-26|last1=Fong|first1=Dominique}}{{Cite newspaper|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/22/business/international/indonesia-economy-interest-rates.html?_r=0|title=Higher Interest Rates Lower Expectations in Emerging Economies|journal=The New York Times|date=2015-12-21|access-date=|last1=Gough|first1=Neil}} His eldest daughter Imelda is a member of the RGE executive committee{{Cite web|url=http://whartonmagazine.com/issues/fall-winter-2017/the-business-family-imelda-tanoto-belinda-tanoto-anderson-tanoto/#sthash.BSUZiiH7.dpbs|title=Wharton Magazine - The Business Family: Imelda Tanoto W04 & Belinda Tanoto C06 W06 & Anderson Tanoto W11|last=|first=|date=2017-10-12|website=|access-date=}} while his younger daughter [[Belinda Tanoto|Belinda]] dedicates most of her time to the family's philanthropic arm, [[Tanoto Foundation]]. All four of Tanoto's children are also trustee members at Tanoto Foundation.{{Cite web|url=http://whartonmagazine.com/issues/fall-winter-2017/the-business-family-imelda-tanoto-belinda-tanoto-anderson-tanoto/#sthash.BSUZiiH7.dpbs|title=Wharton Magazine -The Business Family: Imelda Tanoto W04 & Belinda Tanoto C06 W06 & Anderson Tanoto W11|last=|first=|date=2017-10-12|website=|access-date=}} ==Business activities== Tanoto's business interests are represented by [[Royal Golden Eagle|the Royal Golden Eagle (RGE)]], a global resource-based group of companies with manufacturing operations in Indonesia, China, Brazil, Canada and Europe, and sales offices worldwide. Since Sukanto Tanoto started his entrepreneurial journey in 1967, the business has grown considerably, with a workforce of over 60,000 people and its assets exceeding US$18 billion.{{Cite news|url=http://www.scmp.com/presented/news/hong-kong/education/topics/hkust-biz-school-magazine/article/2115113/outward-looking|title=South China Morning Post: The Outward-looking Family Philanthropy|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171013025434/http://www.scmp.com/presented/news/hong-kong/education/topics/hkust-biz-school-magazine/article/2115113/outward-looking|archive-date=2017-10-13|dead-url=yes}} The business has five key operational areas: pulp and paper ([[Asia Pacific Resources International Holdings]] or APRIL, Asia Symbol), agro-industry ([[Asian Agri]]), specialty cellulose ([[Bracell Limited]]) and viscose fibre ([[Sateri]]) and energy resources development [http://www.po-and-g.com/ (Pacific Oil & Gas)]. APRIL has been involved in conservation controversies related to the use of native Sumatran growth forests,{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/foreign/content/2011/s3283804.htm|title=Paper/Tiger|last=|first=|date=|work=|publisher=ABC Foreign Correspondent|access-date=|via=}} which led to the company withdrawing from the [[Forest Stewardship Council]] in April 2010. In September 2011, [[Fuji Xerox]] ceased selling paper manufactured by APRIL.{{cite news| publisher=Fuji Xerox | title=Fuji Xerox ceases procurement from Asia Pacific Resources International Limited (APRIL)| url=http://www.fujixerox.com/eng/company/ecology/topics/2011/0901_april.html}} The company has denied the claims, stating it has a commitment to implement practices that mitigate climate change and promote sustainability.{{cite web|date=November 2011|title=APRIL's commitment to being part of the "sustainability solution"| url=http://www.aprilasia.com/images/pdfs/APRIL%27s%20commitment%20to%20being%20part%20of%20the%20sustainability%20solution%20-%20by%20AJ%20Devanesan,%20COO%20APRIL.pdf|publisher=|language=|last=Devanesan|first=A.J.|accessdate=28 April 2014}} Furthermore, in June 2015, APRIL pledged to eliminate deforestation from its entire supply chain. The announcement was well received by both Greenpeace and the World Wildlife Fund.{{cite news| publisher=The Jakarta Globe| title=APRIL, APP Get Forest Certification from PEFC | url=http://thejakartaglobe.beritasatu.com/business/forest-certification-pefc/}} In early 2016, Tanoto announced an update of the RGE groupwide business principles - to do what is good for community, country, climate and company.{{cite news| publisher=Inside RGE| title=Sukanto Tanoto announces Fourth C. WEF Davos highlights & behind-the-scenes | url=http://www.inside-rge.com/Sukanto-Tanoto-Fourth-C-WEF-Davos}} In 2017, marking his 50th year as an entrepreneur, Sukanto Tanoto introduced 'Customer' as the fifth C.{{Cite web|url=http://www.inside-rge.com/corporate/rge-founder-chairman-sukanto-tanoto-marks-50-years-business-launching-core-values/|title=RGE marks its 50th year in business|last=|first=|date=2017-09-25|website=|access-date=}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.scmp.com/presented/news/hong-kong/education/topics/hkust-biz-school-magazine/article/2115113/outward-looking|title=South China Morning Post:The Outward-looking Family Philanthropy|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171013025434/http://www.scmp.com/presented/news/hong-kong/education/topics/hkust-biz-school-magazine/article/2115113/outward-looking|archive-date=2017-10-13|dead-url=yes}} == Philanthropic activities == Tanoto and his wife, Tinah Bingei Tanoto, began their philanthropic work in 1981 in Indonesia with the opening of a kindergarten in Besitang.{{cite web |title=Commitment To A Cause: The Continuing Evolution Of The Tanoto Foundation |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/tanotofoundation/2018/11/06/commitment-to-a-cause-the-continuing-evolution-of-the-tanoto-foundation/ |website=Forbes |publisher=Forbes |accessdate=8 November 2018}} They formally established the [[Tanoto Foundation]]{{Cite web|url=http://www.tanotofoundation.org/sukanto-tanoto|title=Tanoto Foundation Founder: Sukanto Tanoto|last=|first=|date=2015-09-08|website=|access-date=}} in 2001. Its numerous educational initiatives have included the funding of teacher training and the provision of over 700 scholarships a year. The Foundation also delivers basic amenities such as clean water and sanitation, as well as healthcare. Through the provision of access to productive assets, startup capital, technical skills and links to markets, it helps to empower families and deliver sustainable livelihood. Tanoto recognized the importance of establishing strong [[corporate social responsibility]] (CSR) programs in the [[Riau]] province. Through [[Riau Andalan Pulp & Paper]] (RAPP), Tanoto built schools and established farming systems that teach villagers an alternative cultivation to [[slash-and-burn]] techniques, as well making regular sustainability reports to [[NGO]]s, such as the [[World Wildlife Fund]] after the organization expressed concerns over the conservation of forests in Riau.{{cite news| publisher=The Jakarta Post| title=Pulp mills put heavy pressure on forests: Study | url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/yesterdaydetail.asp?fileid=20020209.J04 |date=2002-02-09 |accessdate=2007-10-15 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071117043333/http://www.thejakartapost.com/yesterdaydetail.asp?fileid=20020209.J04 |archivedate = 2007-11-17}} The reach of Tanoto Foundation's activities now extends to China, Hong Kong and Singapore and the US. It has provided more than 20,000 scholarships, built several schools and educational facilities that produced 27,000 graduates, developed 60,000 hectares of community livelihood plantations and created more than 1,800 jobs in local communities through Small-and-Medium-size Enterprise (SME) programs.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ust.hk/about-hkust/media-relations/press-releases/bizinsighthkust-forum-examines-future-chinese-family-businesses/#|title=BizInsight@HKUST Forum Examines the Future of Chinese Family Businesses|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} Sukanto Tanoto{{cite web|url=http://www.tanotofoundation.org/sukanto-tanoto|title=Sukanto Tanoto, a Sustainability-Focused and Successful Businessman|date=8 September 2015|publisher=}} also awards professorship awards. In 2007, the award valued at US$130,000 was granted to two Indonesian academic scientists for their efforts to enable socially-responsible technological research programs. He also funds a support professorship in [[metabolism]] and [[endocrinology]] at the [[Duke-NUS Graduate Medical School]] in [[Singapore]] and is a regular donor to [[Carnegie Mellon]], where his contributions fund the ''Tanoto Professor of Electrical and Computer Engineering'' position.{{cite web|url=http://users.ece.cmu.edu/~pileggi/|title=Larry Pileggi, Tanoto Professor of Electrical and Computer Engineering|publisher=Carnegie Mellon University}} Three other professorship awards in the area of oncology,{{Cite web|url=http://www.inside-rge.com/fighting-the-good-fight-tanoto-foundation-boosts-the-fight-against-cancer/|title=Tanoto Professorship in Oncology|last=|first=|date=2017-09-07|website=|access-date=}} diabetes{{Cite web|url=http://www.inside-rge.com/empowering-lives/fighting-good-fight-tanoto-foundation-boosts-fight-diabetes/|title=Tanoto Professorship in Diabetes|last=|first=|date=2017-08-10|website=|access-date=}} and cardiovascular diseases{{Cite web|url=http://www.inside-rge.com/fighting-the-good-fight-tanoto-foundations-boosts-the-fight-against-cardiovascular-disease/|title=Tanoto Professorship: Cardiovascular Disease|last=|first=|date=2017-07-27|website=|access-date=}} were also awarded in year 2016, 2013, 2014 respectively. The Foundation has also supported disaster relief efforts across Asia.{{Cite web|url=http://www.po-and-g.com/about-us/sukanto-tanoto|title=About the Founder|website=www.po-and-g.com|access-date=2016-11-25}} Tanoto donated the building of the [[INSEAD]] library in [[Singapore]] in 2005, which was renamed ''Tanoto Library'' in 2005.{{cite web| publisher=INSEAD| title=About Tanoto Library | url=https://www.insead.edu/library/about_library/tanoto_registration.cfm| date=2015-10-06 }} He was the first donor to the construction of the [[Beijing National Stadium]] in 2006.{{cite web| publisher=China Daily | title=Serve the people | url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/english/doc/2006-03/06/content_526902.htm}} He also donated to the building of the [[Beijing National Aquatics Center]].{{cite web| publisher=iCNTV 对话 官方频道 Dialogue Official Channel | title=对话20110827 对话：华商领袖陈江和Chen Jiang and-HD高清完整版 | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h5163EsYKyg}} Tanoto Foundation and the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania launched the Tanoto Initiative in July 2013. It is a multi-component program to promote studies and research on ASEAS, with a focus on Indonesia.{{Cite web|url=https://news.wharton.upenn.edu/press-releases/2013/07/tanoto-foundation-international-and-wharton-launch-tanoto-initiative-for-indonesian-and-asean-studies/|title=Wharton News: Tanoto Initiative|last=|first=|date=2013-07-29|website=|access-date=}} The Wharton faculty works closely with selected Indonesian universities to offer research grants, academic courses, exchange programs and scholarships aimed at deepening thought leadership and business education in the ASEAN region.{{Cite web|url=https://global.wharton.upenn.edu/organizations/wharton-tanoto-initiative/|title=Wharton News: Tanoto Initiative|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} Tanoto donated 30 million yuan for the construction of a public library in [[Rizhao]], [[Shandong]], [[China]] in 2010. He later donated 200,000 children's books to a public library in June 2016.{{cite web| publisher=Weixin QQ| title=这是真的！全市小朋友收到了500万元的儿童节大礼！ | url=http://mp.weixin.qq.com/s?__biz=MzA4OTM2NjIxOQ==&mid=2650042919&idx=1&sn=93ce0d38cb4680962050ad9a9c2a6fe8#rd}}{{cite web| publisher=Weixin QQ| title=金鹰集团向日照再捐500万！ | url=http://mp.weixin.qq.com/s?__biz=MzI0ODI4NTAwMQ==&mid=2661930039&idx=2&sn=804c3e9dc204c3ecc2cbdc5064b2b086#rd}} In Dec 2015, Tanoto launched the Tanoto Forestry Information Center at the [[Bogor Agricultural University]]. The Center supports the development of forestry science in Indonesia.{{cite web| publisher=Yahoo! Finance| title=Sukanto Tanoto Inaugurates Forestry Knowledge Hub Tanoto Forestry Information Center | url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/sukanto-tanoto-inaugurates-forestry-knowledge-094500552.html}} In Feb 2016, it was announced Tanoto Foundation would collaborate with the [[United Nations Development Programme]] to support work with the Riau provincial governments in implementing sustainable development goals at provincial and district levels.{{cite web| publisher=Jakarta Globe| title= Commentary: From Wall Street to Villages, Indonesia Needs Innovative Financing to Achieve SDGs | url=http://jakartaglobe.beritasatu.com/opinion/commentary-wall-street-villages-indonesia-needs-innovative-financing-achieve-sdgs/}}{{cite web| publisher=Partnerships for SDGs| title=Support the Roll-Out of the SDGs in Indonesia | url=https://sustainabledevelopment.un.org/partnership/?p=11240}}{{cite web| publisher=UNDP Indonesia | title=UNDP and Tanoto Foundation to Support SDGs in Indonesia's Riau province | url=http://www.id.undp.org/content/indonesia/en/home/presscenter/pressreleases/2016/02/26/undp-and-tanoto-foundation-to-support-sdgs-in-indonesia-s-riau-province.html}} In March 2016, Tanoto Foundation donated 100 million yuan to fund and develop training programs under the [[One Belt, One Road]] framework for 10 years.{{cite web | publisher=China Education International | title=Tanoto donates 100 Million RMB to OBOR Training Projects | url=http://en.ceiwow.com/maynews/1770.htm}}{{cite web| publisher=PRNewswire | title=Tanoto Foundation Donates RMB 100 Million Training Fund to Support 'One Belt, One Road' Programme | url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/tanoto-foundation-donates-rmb-100-million-training-fund-to-support-one-belt-one-road-programme-300241814.html}} The training program involved collaborations with [[Tsinghua University]], [[Fudan University]] and [[Huaqiao University]].{{cite web | publisher=Tsinghua University | title= The "Belt and Road" Talent Training Program ·Facilities Connectivity Seminar 2018 at Tsinghua University | url=http://goglobal.tsinghua.edu.cn/en/program/p5mocbll0rUz}} In September 2017, Tanoto Foundation renewed its donation to the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology (HKUST)'s Tanoto Centre for Asian Family Business and Entrepreneurship Studies.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ust.hk/about-hkust/media-relations/press-releases/bizinsighthkust-forum-examines-future-chinese-family-businesses/#|title=HKUST Press Release on Tanoto Center|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} == See also == * [[Energy in Indonesia]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Wikiquote}} * [http://www.sukantotanoto.net/ Sukanto Tanoto official biography and references]. * [https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=344552&privcapId=22103197 Sukanto Tanoto biography and references - Bloomberg Version]. * [https://www.forbes.com/profile/sukanto-tanoto/ Sukanto Tanoto biography and references - Forbes Version]. * [http://www.aprilasia.com/en/sukanto-tanoto Sukanto Tanoto biography and references - April Asia Version]. {{DEFAULTSORT:Tanoto, Sukanto}} [[Category:1949 births]] [[Category:Indonesian businesspeople]] [[Category:Indonesian billionaires]] [[Category:Indonesian philanthropists]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Indonesian people of Chinese descent]]

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{chinese name|Tang (董)}} '''Tang Choon Keng''' ({{zh|s=董俊竞|p=Dǒng Jùnjìng}}; 12 September 1901 – 3 September 2000) was a [[Singapore]]an entrepreneur, who founded [[Tangs]] [[department store]] in Singapore. He was popularly known as '''CK Tang'''. Tang has been credited for leading the way for the retail market in Singapore and establishing [[Orchard Road]] as a premier retail district in Singapore.
==Early life== A [[Teochew people|Teochew]], Tang was born at the turn of the 20th century in [[Shantou]], China to a [[Presbyterian]] pastor. He [[emigrate]]d to the [[British colony]] of Singapore in 1923.
In Singapore, Tang began as a [[door-to-door]] salesman peddling hand-made Swatow [[lace]], [[embroidery]] and [[linen]] products. With a [[Renting|hire]]d [[Pulled rickshaw|rickshaw]], Tang carried his goods in a pair of [[tin]] [[Trunk (luggage)|trunk]]s which remained in his possession as a reminder of his humble beginnings. Tang later became known as the "Tin Trunk Man" and the "Curio King" for his [[rags to riches]] legacy.
==Establishment of Tangs== [[File:Tangs department store, Singapore, photographed February 1969 × July 1971.jpg|thumb|Tangs department store, Singapore, photographed February 1969 × July 1971]] In 1932, Tang was able to embark on a larger venture, having accumulated sufficient funds through hard work. He established a department store in 1932 with an initial [[Capital (economics)|capital]] of [[Straits dollar|S$]]3,000. Tang set up his first shop on the first floor of a building on [[River Valley Road]], selling [[craft]] products from China.
Subsequently in 1940, Tang financed the construction of a new building at the corner of [[Mohamed Sultan Road|Jalan Mohamed Sultan]] and River Valley Road to house a new department store. He called the new [[edifice]] ''Gainurn Building'', a variation of his father's name Tang Gan Urn. The department store sold a vast array of [[merchandise]]. By the 1950s, CK Tang had opened several more branches.
In 1958, Tang bought a 1,351-square metre piece of land at the corner of Orchard Road and [[Scotts Road]] at a cost of [[S$]]10,000 to further his vision of expanding his business. Although the site faced the Tai San Ting Cemetery, he felt that it had commercial value as many British housewives in the [[Tanglin]] area could stop by on their way to the [[Downtown Core|city]]. The decision was made against the advice of fellow businessmen who thought Orchard Road was unfashionable then. Years later, when the [[Singapore Government]] designated and developed Orchard Road as a prime shopping and tourist district, the price of land soared from S$3 per m² to S$6,000 per m².
With the acquired land plot, Tang constructed the landmark [[C.K. Tang Department Store]] (now rebranded as Tangs) at 310 Orchard Road at a cost of S$50,000. The building's green-[[tile]]d roof and facade was modelled after the [[Imperial Palace of the Forbidden City]] in Beijing. In 1960, Tang voluntarily closed the store due to problems with the trade unions, but Tangs was re-opened the following year. In 1975, Tang's company was [[Public company|publicly listed]].
[[File:Marriott Hotel 2, Singapore, Dec 05.JPG|thumb|[[Mariott Hotel (Singapore)|Marriott Hotel, Singapore]] (formerly the [[Dynasty Hotel]]) and Tang Plaza were built in 1982 to expand Tang Choon Keng's business on [[Orchard Road]].]] In the late 1970s, Tang expanded his business again when he decided to develop the neighbouring [[property]] lots which he had bought years before. In 1982, the building on Orchard Road was [[demolish]]ed to make way for the new Tang complex, comprising the 33-storey deluxe [[Dynasty Hotel]] (now the [[Singapore Marriott Hotel]]) and the Tangs shopping complex (now Tang Plaza). The shopping complex consists of five floors of retail space covering more than 15,000 m², [[Marketing|marketed]] under the [[slogan]] "All The Best Under One Roof".
In 1991, Tangs opened its first overseas branch in [[Kuala Lumpur]], Malaysia. Tang also collaborated with Malaysia's Mayang Sari Bhd to develop real estate, hotels and commercial properties in Kuala Lumpur. He also assisted the [[Dairy Farm International Holdings]] in its retail business in Malaysia.
Until 1996, Tangs was the only major shopping centre in Singapore to not operate on Sundays, in deference to Tang's Christian faith. Tang instituted the policy so that his family and Christian staff could attend [[Church service|church]] on Sundays. As a staunch Christian, Tang spoke of [[honesty]] and hard work as his guiding [[principle]]s.
Tang's distinctive management philosophy was the focus on people, both customers and staff. Emphasis was given to quality of the staff, reasonable [[pricing]] and warm [[Customer service|service]]. Tang believed in [[invest]]ing in his staff, as his frontline staff would be the ones who would be in direct contact with the customers and he believed that the [[Reputation|image]] of the store depended on them. As a result, Tang reserved a substantial annual [[budget]] for staff [[training]], which included tailored programs for sales staff, [[supervisor]]s and management. Supervisors and [[Management|managers]] were expected to undergo a minimum 100 hours of training. Tang also made an effort to get in touch with his staff at all levels, in order understand his customers' expectations on product and service quality. Despite the company's poor financial results in certain years, Tangs retained its reputation for good service and reliability.
Tang retired in 1987, handing the reins of [[corporate]] leadership to the second of his three sons, [[Tang Wee Sung]]. Tang retained the post of company president and was rarely out of touch with company business, personally checking the company's [[account (accountancy)|accounts]] and meeting suppliers.
== Personal life == Besides CK Tang, Tang Choon Keng was also known as Tang Un Tien.
In 1960, Tang was [[kidnap]]ped by four armed thugs, but was freed unharmed within 84 hours after the family reportedly paid S$150,000 in [[ransom]].
Tang's first wife died in 1980; he subsequently remarried. Tang had eight children. On 3 September 2000, Tang died peacefully at home with his family around him at 98 years old.
== Death == Tang died on 3 September 2000 in Singapore.
== References == * {{cite web|url= http://infopedia.nlb.gov.sg/articles/SIP_534_2005-01-09.html|title= Singapore Infopedia: C. K. Tang (Tang Choon Keng)|accessdate= 20 July 2007|work= [[National Library Board]]|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070704214732/http://infopedia.nlb.gov.sg/articles/SIP_534_2005-01-09.html|archivedate= 4 July 2007|df= dmy-all}} * {{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/910026.stm|title=Singapore retail tycoon dies|accessdate=20 July 2007|publisher=[[BBC News]] | date=4 September 2000}} * {{cite news|url=http://www.asiaweek.com/asiaweek/magazine/2000/0915/newsmakers.html|title=Passage: Tang Choon Keng|accessdate=20 July 2007|publisher=[[Asiaweek]]}} * {{cite web|url= http://www.haoyah.com/gongshang/dongtai35.asp|title= 新加坡華裔百貨大王去世 (in Mandarin)|accessdate= 20 July 2007|format= |work= HaoYah.com|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071028185606/http://www.haoyah.com/gongshang/dongtai35.asp|archivedate= 28 October 2007|df= dmy-all}} * {{cite web|url= http://www.chaonet.net/chaoren/daheng/30pop.htm|title= 董俊竞: "以人为本谋发展" (in Mandarin)|accessdate= 20 July 2007|work= Chaonet.net|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070608225429/http://www.chaonet.net/chaoren/daheng/30pop.htm|archivedate= 8 June 2007|df= dmy-all}}
==External links== * [http://www.tangs.com/ Official website of Tangs]
